   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Spanish language
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div class="noprint" id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>
    <div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
     Jump to:
     <a href="#mw-head">
      navigation
     </a>
     ,
     <a href="#p-search">
      search
     </a>
    </div>
    <div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       "Español" and "Espagnol" redirect here. For other uses, see
       <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Espa%C3%B1ol_(disambiguation)" title="Español (disambiguation)">
        Español (disambiguation)
       </a>
       . For the wine grape, see
       <a href="/wiki/Argant" title="Argant">
        Argant
       </a>
       .
      </div>

          </a>
         </span>
         ,

         ,

         <a href="#Geographical_distribution">
          more
         </a>
         )

        <th scope="row" style="padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em; padding-right:0.5em;">
         <div style="padding:0.1em 0;line-height:1.2em;">
          Native speakers
         </div>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         480 million (2017)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-1">
           [1]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <br/>
         570 million total speakers
         <br/>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/L2_speakers" title="L2 speakers">
          L2 speakers
         </a>
         : 90 million (no date)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EthnologueSp_2-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-EthnologueSp-2">
           [2]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>

         </a>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_of_Spanish_Language_Academies" title="Association of Spanish Language Academies">
          Association of Spanish Language Academies
         </a>
         <br/>
         <small>
          (
          <i>
           <span lang="es">
            <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Real Academia Española">
             Real Academia Española
            </a>
           </span>
          </i>
          and 22 other national Spanish language academies)
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;color: black; background-color:  #c9ffd9;">
         Language codes
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em; padding-right:0.5em;">
         <span class="nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/ISO_639-1" title="ISO 639-1">
           ISO 639-1
          </a>
         </span>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         <code>
          <span class="plainlinks">
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/langcodes_name.php?iso_639_1=es" rel="nofollow">
            es
           </a>
          </span>
         </code>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em; padding-right:0.5em;">
         <span class="nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/ISO_639-2" title="ISO 639-2">
           ISO 639-2
          </a>
         </span>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         <code>
          <span class="plainlinks">
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.loc.gov/standards/iso639-2/php/langcodes_name.php?code_ID=422" rel="nofollow">
            spa
           </a>
          </span>
         </code>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em; padding-right:0.5em;">
         <span class="nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/ISO_639-3" title="ISO 639-3">
           ISO 639-3
          </a>
         </span>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         <code>
          <a class="extiw" href="http://www-01.sil.org/iso639-3/documentation.asp?id=spa" title="iso639-3:spa">
           spa
          </a>
         </code>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em; padding-right:0.5em;">
         <a href="/wiki/Glottolog" title="Glottolog">
          Glottolog
         </a>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         <code>
          <a class="external text" href="http://glottolog.org/resource/languoid/id/stan1288" rel="nofollow">
           stan1288
          </a>
         </code>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Glottolog_3-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Glottolog-3">
           [3]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th scope="row" style="padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em; padding-right:0.5em;">
         <a href="/wiki/Linguasphere_Observatory" title="Linguasphere Observatory">
          Linguasphere
         </a>
        </th>
        <td style="line-height:1.35em;">
         <code>
          51-AAA-b
         </code>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;line-height:1.35em;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map-Hispanophone_World2.png">
          <img alt="Map-Hispanophone World2.png" data-file-height="1468" data-file-width="2636" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Map-Hispanophone_World2.png/220px-Map-Hispanophone_World2.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Map-Hispanophone_World2.png/330px-Map-Hispanophone_World2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Map-Hispanophone_World2.png/440px-Map-Hispanophone_World2.png 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
         <div style="text-align:left;">
          Spanish language in the world
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td class="noprint selfref" colspan="2" style="text-align:center;background-color:#ddddff;padding:0.3em 0.5em;text-align:left;line-height:1.3;">
         <b>
          This article contains
          <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
           IPA
          </a>
          phonetic symbols.
         </b>
         Without proper
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Fonts" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          rendering support
         </a>
         , you may see
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Replacement_character" title="Replacement character">
          question marks, boxes, or other symbols
         </a>
         instead of
         <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
          Unicode
         </a>
         characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">
          Help:IPA
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The
       <b>
        Spanish language
       </b>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'s' in 'sigh'">
            s
           </span>
           <span title="'p' in 'pie'">
            p
           </span>
           <span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">
            æ
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
           <span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">
            ɪ
           </span>
           <span title="/ʃ/: 'sh' in 'shy'">
            ʃ
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Spanish.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/En-us-Spanish.ogg" title="En-us-Spanish.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ;
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Espanolpronunciation.ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4d/Espanolpronunciation.ogg" title="Espanolpronunciation.ogg">
          <i>
           Español
          </i>
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a href="/wiki/File:Espanolpronunciation.ogg" title="File:Espanolpronunciation.ogg">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ), also called the
       <b>
        Castilian language
       </b>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4">
        <a href="#cite_note-4">
         [4]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (
       <span class="nowrap">
        <span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt">
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">
          /
          <span style="border-bottom:1px dotted">
           <span title="'k' in 'kind'">
            k
           </span>
           <span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">
            æ
           </span>
           <span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">
            ˈ
           </span>
           <span title="'s' in 'sigh'">
            s
           </span>
           <span title="'t' in 'tie'">
            t
           </span>
           <span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">
            ɪ
           </span>
           <span title="'l' in 'lie'">
            l
           </span>
           <span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">
            i
           </span>
           <span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">
            ə
           </span>
           <span title="'n' in 'nigh'">
            n
           </span>
          </span>
          /
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="nowrap">
         (
         <span class="unicode haudio">
          <span class="fn">
           <span style="white-space:nowrap">
            <a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Castilian.ogg" title="About this sound">
             <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
            </a>
           </span>
           <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/78/En-us-Castilian.ogg" title="En-us-Castilian.ogg">
            listen
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="unicode haudio">
        <span class="fn">
         <span style="white-space:nowrap">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Es_castellano_001.ogg" title="About this sound">
           <img alt="About this sound" data-file-height="20" data-file-width="20" height="11" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" width="11"/>
          </a>
         </span>
         <a class="internal" href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fc/Es_castellano_001.ogg" title="Es castellano 001.ogg">
          <i>
           castellano
          </i>
         </a>
        </span>
        <small class="metadata audiolinkinfo" style="cursor:help;">
         (
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Media_help" title="Wikipedia:Media help">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           help
          </span>
         </a>
         ·
         <a href="/wiki/File:Es_castellano_001.ogg" title="File:Es castellano 001.ogg">
          <span style="cursor:help;">
           info
          </span>
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </span>
       ), is a
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Romance_languages" title="Western Romance languages">
        West Romance language
       </a>
       that originated in the
       <a href="/wiki/Castile_(historical_region)" title="Castile (historical region)">
        Castile
       </a>
       region of
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       and today has hundreds of millions of native speakers around the world. It is usually considered the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
        world's second-most spoken native language
       </a>
       , after
       <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">
        Mandarin Chinese
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nationalencyklopedin_5-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Nationalencyklopedin-5">
         [5]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
        <a href="#cite_note-6">
         [6]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7">
        <a href="#cite_note-7">
         [7]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-8">
        <a href="#cite_note-8">
         [8]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
        <a href="#cite_note-9">
         [9]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is a part of the
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Romance_languages" title="Iberian Romance languages">
        Ibero-Romance group of languages
       </a>
       , which evolved from several dialects of
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">
        Iberia
       </a>
       after the collapse of the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">
        Western Roman Empire
       </a>
       in the 5th century. The oldest Latin texts with traces of Spanish come from mid-northern Iberia in the 9th century,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10">
        <a href="#cite_note-10">
         [10]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and the first systematic written use of the language happened in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toledo_(Spain)" title="Toledo (Spain)">
        Toledo
       </a>
       , then capital of the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile" title="Kingdom of Castile">
        Kingdom of Castile
       </a>
       , in the 13th century. Beginning in the early 16th century, Spanish was taken to the colonies of the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spanish Empire
       </a>
       , most notably to
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">
        the Americas
       </a>
       , as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire#Territories_in_Africa_(1885–1975)" title="Spanish Empire">
        territories in Africa
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">
        Oceania
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">
        Philippines
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11">
        <a href="#cite_note-11">
         [11]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Around 75% of modern Spanish vocabulary is derived from
       <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
        Latin
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">
        Ancient Greek
       </a>
       has also contributed substantially to Spanish vocabulary, especially through Latin, where it had a great impact.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12">
        <a href="#cite_note-12">
         [12]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13">
        <a href="#cite_note-13">
         [13]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish vocabulary has been in contact from an early date with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_influence_on_the_Spanish_language" title="Arabic influence on the Spanish language">
        Arabic
       </a>
       , having developed during the
       <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">
        Al-Andalus
       </a>
       era in the Iberian Peninsula.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dworkin83_14-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dworkin83-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15">
        <a href="#cite_note-15">
         [15]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-16">
        <a href="#cite_note-16">
         [16]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17">
        <a href="#cite_note-17">
         [17]
        </a>
       </sup>
       With around 8% of its vocabulary being Arabic in origin, this language is the second most important influence after Latin.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dworkin83_14-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dworkin83-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-18">
        <a href="#cite_note-18">
         [18]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19">
        <a href="#cite_note-19">
         [19]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It has also been influenced by
       <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">
        Basque
       </a>
       as well as by neighboring Ibero-Romance languages.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dworkin83_14-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Dworkin83-14">
         [14]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It also adopted words from non-Iberian languages such as
       <a href="/wiki/Gothic_language" title="Gothic language">
        Gothic language
       </a>
       from the
       <a href="/wiki/Visigoths" title="Visigoths">
        Visigoths
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
        <a href="#cite_note-20">
         [20]
        </a>
       </sup>
       . It has absorbed vocabulary from other languages, particularly the Romance languages
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
        Occitan
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Sardinian_language" title="Sardinian language">
        Sardinian
       </a>
       , as well as from
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Spanish_words_of_Nahuatl_origin" title="List of Spanish words of Nahuatl origin">
        Nahuatl
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Quechuan_languages" title="Quechuan languages">
        Quechua
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_Spanish_words_of_Indigenous_American_Indian_origin" title="List of Spanish words of Indigenous American Indian origin">
        other indigenous languages of the Americas
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is one of the
       <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations" title="Official languages of the United Nations">
        six official languages
       </a>
       of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       . It is also used as an
       <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
        official language
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">
        Organization of American States
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Union_of_South_American_Nations" title="Union of South American Nations">
        Union of South American Nations
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Community_of_Latin_American_and_Caribbean_States" title="Community of Latin American and Caribbean States">
        Community of Latin American and Caribbean States
       </a>
       , and by
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_where_Spanish_is_an_official_language#International_organizations_where_Spanish_is_official" title="List of countries where Spanish is an official language">
        many other international organizations
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
        <a href="#cite_note-21">
         [21]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
      </p>
      <div class="toc" id="toc">
       <div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en">

        </h2>

        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4">

        </li>

         <ul>

          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8">
         <a href="#Geographical_distribution">
          <span class="tocnumber">
           6
          </span>
          <span class="toctext">
           Geographical distribution
          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-9">
           <a href="#Europe">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.1
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Europe
            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10">
           <a href="#Americas">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.2
            </span>
            <span class="toctext">
             Americas
            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-11">
             <a href="#Hispanic_America">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               6.2.1
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               Hispanic America
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-12">
             <a href="#United_States">
              <span class="tocnumber">
               6.2.2
              </span>
              <span class="toctext">
               United States
              </span>
             </a>
            </li>
           </ul>
          </li>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-13">
           <a href="#Africa">
            <span class="tocnumber">
             6.3
            </span>

             Africa
            </span>

          </li>

           </a>
          </li>

            </span>
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-16">
         <a href="#Dialectal_variation">
          <span class="tocnumber">

          </span>
         </a>
         <ul>
          <li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-17">

            </span>
           </a>
           <ul>
            <li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-19">

              <span class="tocnumber">

              </span>
             </a>
             <ul>
              <li class="toclevel-4 tocsection-20">

                </span>

             </ul>
            </li>

      </div>
      <p>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Estimated_number_of_speakers">
        Estimated number of speakers
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Estimated number of speakers">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <p>
       It is estimated that more than 437 million people speak Spanish as a
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Native_language" title="Native language">
        native language
       </a>
       , which qualifies it as second on the
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
        lists of languages by number of native speakers
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
        <a href="#cite_note-22">
         [22]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Cervantes" title="Instituto Cervantes">
        Instituto Cervantes
       </a>
       claims that there are an estimated 477 million Spanish speakers with native competence and 572 million Spanish speakers as a first or second language—including speakers with limited competence—and more than 21 million students of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_as_a_foreign_language" title="Spanish as a foreign language">
        Spanish as a foreign language
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-InstitutoCervantes_23-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-InstitutoCervantes-23">
         [23]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is the official or national language in Spain,
       <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_America" title="Hispanic America">
        19 countries in the Americas
       </a>
       .
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Americas" title="Spanish language in the Americas">
        Speakers in the Americas
       </a>
       total some 418 million. In the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , Spanish is the mother tongue of 8% of the population, with an additional 7% speaking it as a second language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
        <a href="#cite_note-24">
         [24]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Spanish is the most popular second language learned in the
       <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">
        United States
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
        <a href="#cite_note-25">
         [25]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2011 it was estimated by the
       <a href="/wiki/American_Community_Survey" title="American Community Survey">
        American Community Survey
       </a>
       that of the 55 million Hispanic United States residents who are five years of age and over, 38 million speak Spanish at home.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
        <a href="#cite_note-26">
         [26]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Names_of_the_language">
        Names of the language
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Names of the language">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Names_given_to_the_Spanish_language" title="Names given to the Spanish language">
        Names given to the Spanish language
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg">
           <img alt="Crystal Clear app kedit.svg" data-file-height="128" data-file-width="128" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/40px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/60px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg/80px-Crystal_Clear_app_kedit.svg.png 2x" width="40"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section may need to be
          <b>
           rewritten entirely
          </b>
          to comply with Wikipedia's
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style">
           quality standards
          </a>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit">
            You can help
           </a>
           . The
           <a href="/wiki/Talk:Spanish_language" title="Talk:Spanish language">
            discussion page
           </a>
           may contain suggestions.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (December 2014)
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="922" data-file-width="694" height="372" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png/280px-Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png/420px-Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png/560px-Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png 2x" width="280"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Castellano-Espa%C3%B1ol.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Geographical distribution of the preferential use of the terms
         <i>
          castellano
         </i>
         (Castilian), in red, vs.
         <i>
          español
         </i>
         (Spanish), in blue, according to the terminology found in these countries' legal constitutions.
         <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
          [
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
            <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2014)">
             citation needed
            </span>
           </a>
          </i>
          ]
         </sup>
         <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
          [
          <i>
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute">
            <span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (November 2017)">
             dubious
            </span>
           </a>
           <span class="metadata">
            –
            <a href="/wiki/Talk:Spanish_language#Dubious" title="Talk:Spanish language">
             discuss
            </a>
           </span>
          </i>
          ]
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In Spain and in some other parts of the Spanish-speaking world, Spanish is called not only
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/espa%C3%B1ol#Spanish" title="wikt:español">
          español
         </a>
        </span>
       </i>
       (Spanish) but also
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/castellano#Spanish" title="wikt:castellano">
          castellano
         </a>
        </span>
       </i>
       (Castilian), the language from the
       <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Castile" title="Kingdom of Castile">
        kingdom of Castile
       </a>
       , contrasting it with other
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Spain" title="Languages of Spain">
        languages spoken in Spain
       </a>
       such as
       <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
        Galician
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">
        Basque
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Asturian_language" title="Asturian language">
        Asturian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
        Catalan
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_Constitution_of_1978" title="Spanish Constitution of 1978">
        Spanish Constitution of 1978
       </a>
       uses the term
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          castellano
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       to define the
       <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">
        official language
       </a>
       of the whole Spanish State in contrast to
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          las demás lenguas españolas
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       (lit. "the other
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_languages" title="Spanish languages">
        Spanish languages
       </a>
       "). Article III reads as follows:
      </p>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>
        <i>
         <span lang="es">
          <i>
           El castellano es la lengua española oficial del Estado. ... Las demás lenguas españolas serán también oficiales en las respectivas Comunidades Autónomas...
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        <br/>
       </p>
       <p>
        Castilian is the official Spanish language of the State. ... The other Spanish languages shall also be official in their respective Autonomous Communities...
       </p>
      </blockquote>
      <p>
       The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Real Academia Española">
        Spanish Royal Academy
       </a>
       , on the other hand, currently uses the term
       <i>
        español
       </i>
       in its publications, but from 1713 to 1923 called the language
       <i>
        castellano
       </i>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Diccionario_panhisp%C3%A1nico_de_dudas" title="Diccionario panhispánico de dudas">
         Diccionario panhispánico de dudas
        </a>
       </i>
       (a language guide published by the Spanish Royal Academy) states that, although the Spanish Royal Academy prefers to use the term
       <i>
        español
       </i>
       in its publications when referring to the Spanish language, both terms—
       <i>
        español
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        castellano
       </i>
       —are regarded as synonymous and equally valid.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
        <a href="#cite_note-27">
         [27]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Two etymologies for
       <i>
        español
       </i>
       have been suggested. The
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diccionario_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola_de_la_Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Diccionario de la lengua española de la Real Academia Española">
        Spanish Royal Academy Dictionary
       </a>
       derives the term from the
       <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
        Provençal
       </a>
       word
       <i>
        espaignol
       </i>
       , and that in turn from the Medieval Latin word
       <i>
        Hispaniolus
       </i>
       , 'from—or pertaining to—Hispania'.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
        <a href="#cite_note-28">
         [28]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Other authorities
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
        <a href="#cite_note-29">
         [29]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30">
        <a href="#cite_note-30">
         [30]
        </a>
       </sup>
       attribute it to a supposed mediaeval Latin *
       <i>
        hispaniōne
       </i>
       , with the same meaning.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
        History
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: History">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Spanish_language" title="History of the Spanish language">
        History of the Spanish language
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:227px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CartulariosValpuesta.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="145" data-file-width="255" height="128" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/CartulariosValpuesta.jpg/225px-CartulariosValpuesta.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8c/CartulariosValpuesta.jpg 1.5x" width="225"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CartulariosValpuesta.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The Visigothic
         <a href="/wiki/Cartularies_of_Valpuesta" title="Cartularies of Valpuesta">
          Cartularies of Valpuesta
         </a>
         , written in a late form of Latin, were declared in 2010 by the Spanish Royal Academy as the record of the earliest words written in Castilian, predating those of the
         <a href="/wiki/Glosas_Emilianenses" title="Glosas Emilianenses">
          Glosas Emilianenses
         </a>
         .
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
          <a href="#cite_note-31">
           [31]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Spanish language evolved from
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       , which was brought to the
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Peninsula" title="Iberian Peninsula">
        Iberian Peninsula
       </a>
       by the
       <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">
        Romans
       </a>
       during the
       <a href="/wiki/Second_Punic_War" title="Second Punic War">
        Second Punic War
       </a>
       , beginning in 210 BC. Previously, several pre-Roman languages (also called
       <a href="/wiki/Paleohispanic_languages" title="Paleohispanic languages">
        Paleohispanic languages
       </a>
       )—unrelated to Latin, and some of them unrelated even to Indo-European—were spoken in the Iberian Peninsula. These languages included
       <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">
        Basque
       </a>
       (still spoken today),
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_language" title="Iberian language">
        Iberian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Celtiberian_language" title="Celtiberian language">
        Celtiberian
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">
        Celtic
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The first documents to show traces of what is today regarded as the precursor of modern Spanish are from the 9th century. Throughout the
       <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">
        Middle Ages
       </a>
       and into the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_era" title="Modern era">
        modern era
       </a>
       , the most important influences on the Spanish lexicon came from neighboring
       <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">
        Romance languages
       </a>
       —
       <a href="/wiki/Navarro-Aragonese" title="Navarro-Aragonese">
        Navarro-Aragonese
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonese_language" title="Leonese language">
        Leonese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
        Catalan
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
        Galician
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
        Occitan
       </a>
       , and later,
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
        Italian
       </a>
       . Spanish also borrowed a considerable number of words from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">
        Arabic
       </a>
       , as well as a minor influence from
       <a href="/wiki/Germanic_languages" title="Germanic languages">
        Germanic languages
       </a>
       through the migration of tribes and a period of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Visigoth" title="Visigoth">
        Visigoth
       </a>
       rule in Iberia. In addition, many more words were borrowed from
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_language" title="Latin language">
        Latin
       </a>
       through the influence of written language and the liturgical language of the Church. The loanwords were taken from both
       <a href="/wiki/Classical_Latin" title="Classical Latin">
        Classical Latin
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Renaissance_Latin" title="Renaissance Latin">
        Renaissance Latin
       </a>
       , the form of Latin in use at that time.
      </p>
      <p>
       According to the theories of
       <a href="/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_Men%C3%A9ndez_Pidal" title="Ramón Menéndez Pidal">
        Ramón Menéndez Pidal
       </a>
       , local
       <a href="/wiki/Sociolect" title="Sociolect">
        sociolects
       </a>
       of Vulgar Latin evolved into Spanish, in the north of Iberia, in an area centered in the city of
       <a href="/wiki/Burgos" title="Burgos">
        Burgos
       </a>
       , and this dialect was later brought to the city of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toledo_(Spain)" title="Toledo (Spain)">
        Toledo
       </a>
       , where the written standard of Spanish was first developed, in the 13th century.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Penny1_32-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Penny1-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In this formative stage, Spanish developed a strongly differing variant from its close cousin,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonese_Language" title="Leonese Language">
        Leonese
       </a>
       , and, according to some authors, was distinguished by a heavy Basque influence (see
       <a href="/wiki/Iberian_Romance_languages" title="Iberian Romance languages">
        Iberian Romance languages
       </a>
       ). This distinctive dialect spread to southern Spain with the advance of the
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Reconquista" title="Reconquista">
           Reconquista
          </a>
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , and meanwhile gathered a sizable lexical influence from the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">
        Arabic
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">
        Al-Andalus
       </a>
       , much of it indirectly, through the Romance
       <a href="/wiki/Mozarabic_language" title="Mozarabic language">
        Mozarabic dialects
       </a>
       (some 4,000
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">
        Arabic
       </a>
       -derived words, make up around 8% of the language today).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
        <a href="#cite_note-33">
         [33]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The written standard for this new language was developed in the cities of
       <a href="/wiki/Toledo,_Spain" title="Toledo, Spain">
        Toledo
       </a>
       , in the 13th to 16th centuries, and
       <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">
        Madrid
       </a>
       , from the 1570s.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Penny1_32-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Penny1-32">
         [32]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       The development of the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_phonology" title="Spanish phonology">
        Spanish sound system
       </a>
       from that of
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       exhibits most of the changes that are typical of
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Romance_languages" title="Western Romance languages">
        Western Romance languages
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Lenition" title="Lenition">
        lenition
       </a>
       of intervocalic consonants (thus Latin
       <i>
        <span lang="la">
         <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
          vīta
         </span>
        </span>
       </i>
       &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          vida
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ). The
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel_breaking" title="Vowel breaking">
        diphthongization
       </a>
       of Latin stressed short
       <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
        e
       </span>
       and
       <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
        o
       </span>
       —which occurred in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Syllable_coda" title="Syllable coda">
        open syllables
       </a>
       in French and Italian, but not at all in Catalan or Portuguese—is found in both open and closed syllables in Spanish, as shown in the following table:
      </p>
      <div style="overflow:auto;">
       <table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center">
        <tr>
         <th>
          Latin
         </th>
         <th>
          Spanish
         </th>
         <th>
          Ladino
         </th>
         <th>
          Aragonese
         </th>
         <th>
          Asturian
         </th>
         <th>
          Galician
         </th>
         <th>

         </th>
         <th>

         </th>
         <th>
          Gascon / Occitan
         </th>
         <th>
          French
         </th>
         <th>
          Sardinian
         </th>
         <th>

         </th>
         <th>

         </th>
         <th>
          English
         </th>
        </tr>

          </i>
         </td>

           rre
          </i>

          </i>

          <i>

           </b>
           trǎ
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'stone'
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>

         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>

         </td>

          </i>

          </i>

          </i>

          </i>

          </i>
         </td>

          <i>
           mòrti
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           morte
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           m
           <b>
            oa
           </b>
           rte
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'death'
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="544" data-file-width="600" height="199" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif/220px-Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif/330px-Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif/440px-Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_Southwestern_Europe.gif" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Chronological map showing linguistic evolution in southwest Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Spanish is marked by the
       <a href="/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)" title="Palatalization (sound change)">
        palatalization
       </a>
       of the Latin double consonants
       <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
        nn
       </span>
       and
       <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
        ll
       </span>
       (thus Latin
       <i>
        <span lang="la">
         <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
          annum
         </span>
        </span>
       </i>
       &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          año
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , and Latin
       <i>
        <span lang="la">
         <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
          anellum
         </span>
        </span>
       </i>
       &gt; Spanish
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          anillo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       The consonant written
       <i>
        u
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        v
       </i>
       in Latin and pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [w]
       </span>
       in Classical Latin had probably "
       <a href="/wiki/Fortition" title="Fortition">
        fortified
       </a>
       " to a bilabial fricative
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /β/
       </span>
       in Vulgar Latin. In early Spanish (but not in Catalan or Portuguese) it merged with the consonant written
       <i>
        b
       </i>
       (a bilabial with plosive and fricative allophones). In modern Spanish, there is
       <a href="/wiki/Betacism" title="Betacism">
        no difference
       </a>
       between the pronunciation of orthographic
       <i>
        b
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        v
       </i>
       , with some exceptions in Caribbean Spanish.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
          <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2015)">
           citation needed
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Peculiar to Spanish (as well as to the neighboring
       <a href="/wiki/Gascon_language" title="Gascon language">
        Gascon
       </a>
       dialect of
       <a href="/wiki/Occitan_language" title="Occitan language">
        Occitan
       </a>
       , and attributed to a Basque
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Substratum" title="Substratum">
        substratum
       </a>
       ) was the mutation of Latin initial
       <i>
        f
       </i>
       into
       <i>
        h-
       </i>
       whenever it was followed by a vowel that did not diphthongize. The
       <i>
        h-
       </i>
       , still preserved in spelling, is now silent in most varieties of the language, although in some Andalusian and Caribbean dialects it is still aspirated in some words. Because of borrowings from Latin and from neighboring Romance languages, there are many
       <i>
        f
       </i>
       -/
       <i>
        h
       </i>
       -doublets in modern Spanish:
       <i>
        Fernando
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        Hernando
       </i>
       (both Spanish for "Ferdinand"),
       <i>
        ferrero
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        herrero
       </i>
       (both Spanish for "smith"),
       <i>
        fierro
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        hierro
       </i>
       (both Spanish for "iron"), and
       <i>
        fondo
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        hondo
       </i>
       (both Spanish for "deep", but
       <i>
        fondo
       </i>
       means "bottom" while
       <i>
        hondo
       </i>
       means "deep");
       <i>
        hacer
       </i>
       (Spanish for "to make") is cognate to the root word of
       <i>
        satisfacer
       </i>
       (Spanish for "to satisfy"), and
       <i>
        hecho
       </i>
       ("made") is similarly cognate to the root word of
       <i>
        satisfecho
       </i>
       (Spanish for "satisfied").
      </p>
      <p>
       Compare the examples in the following table:
      </p>
      <div style="overflow:auto;">
       <table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center">
        <tr>

         <th>
          English
         </th>
        </tr>

        </tr>

          <i>

          </i>

         </td>

         </td>
        </tr>

          <i>

          </i>

          <i>
           <b>
