           </b>
           uèc
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           feu
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           fogu
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           fuoco
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           foc
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'fire'
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
      <p>
       Some
       <a href="/wiki/Consonant_cluster" title="Consonant cluster">
        consonant clusters
       </a>
       of Latin also produced characteristically different results in these languages, as shown in the examples in the following table:
      </p>
      <div style="overflow:auto;">
       <table class="wikitable" style="text-align: center">
        <tr>
         <th>
          Latin
         </th>
         <th>
          Spanish
         </th>
         <th>
          Ladino
         </th>
         <th>
          Aragonese
         </th>
         <th>
          Asturian
         </th>
         <th>
          Galician
         </th>
         <th>
          Portuguese
         </th>
         <th>
          Catalan
         </th>
         <th>
          Gascon / Occitan
         </th>
         <th>
          French
         </th>
         <th>
          Sardinian
         </th>
         <th>
          Italian
         </th>
         <th>
          Romanian
         </th>
         <th>
          English
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
           <b>
            cl
           </b>
           āvem
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <b>
            ll
           </b>
           ave
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           clave
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           clave
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           clau
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <b>
            ll
           </b>
           ave
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           chave
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           chave
          </i>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <i>
           clau
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           clé
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           crai
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           chiave
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           cheie
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'key'
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
           <b>
            fl
           </b>
           amma
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <b>
            ll
           </b>
           ama
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           flama
          </i>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <i>
           <b>
            fl
           </b>
           ama
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           chama
          </i>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <i>
           chama
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           flama
          </i>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <i>
           flama
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           flamme
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           framma
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           fiamma
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           flamă
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'flame'
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
           <b>
            pl
           </b>
           ēnum
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <b>
            ll
           </b>
           eno
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           pleno
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           pleno
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           plen
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <b>
            ll
           </b>
           enu
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           cheo
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           cheio
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           pleno
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           ple
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           plen
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           plein
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           prenu
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           pieno
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           plin
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'plenty, full'
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
           o
           <b>
            ct
           </b>
           ō
          </span>
         </td>
         <td colspan="2">
          <i>
           o
           <b>
            ch
           </b>
           o
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           güeito
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           o
           <b>
            ch
           </b>
           o
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           oito
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           oito
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           oito
          </i>
          (
          <i>
           oi
           <b>
            t
           </b>
           o
          </i>
          )
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           vuit
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           huit
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           uè
           <b>
            ch
           </b>
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           uò
           <b>
            ch
           </b>
          </i>
          /
          <i>
           uèit
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           huit
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           otu
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           otto
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           opt
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'eight'
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
           mu
           <b>
            lt
           </b>
           um
          </span>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            ch
           </b>
           o
          </i>
          <br/>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            y
           </b>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            nch
           </b>
           o
          </i>
          <br/>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            y
           </b>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           muito
          </i>
          <br/>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            i
           </b>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            nch
           </b>
           u
          </i>
          <br/>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            i
           </b>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           moito
          </i>
          <br/>
          <i>
           mo
           <b>
            i
           </b>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           muito
          </i>
          (
          <i>
           mui
           <b>
            t
           </b>
           o
          </i>
          )
          <br/>
          <i>
           mu
           <b>
            i
           </b>
          </i>
          (arch.)
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           molt
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           molt
          </i>
          (arch.)
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           moult
          </i>
          (arch.)
         </td>
         <td>
          (
          <i>
           meda
          </i>
          )
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           molto
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           mult
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'much,
          <br/>
          very,
          <br/>
          many'
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="806" data-file-width="544" height="252" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg/170px-Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg/255px-Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg/340px-Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Juan_de_Z%C3%BA%C3%B1iga_dibujo_con_orla.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Antonio_de_Nebrija" title="Antonio de Nebrija">
          Antonio de Nebrija
         </a>
         , author of
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Gram%C3%A1tica_de_la_lengua_castellana" title="Gramática de la lengua castellana">
           Gramática de la lengua castellana
          </a>
         </i>
         , the first grammar of modern European languages.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
          <a href="#cite_note-34">
           [34]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In the 15th and 16th centuries, Spanish underwent a dramatic change in the pronunciation of its
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sibilant_consonants" title="Sibilant consonants">
        sibilant consonants
       </a>
       , known in Spanish as the
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reajuste_de_las_sibilantes_del_idioma_espa%C3%B1ol" title="es:Reajuste de las sibilantes del idioma español">
          reajuste de las sibilantes
         </a>
        </span>
       </i>
       , which resulted in the distinctive velar
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [x]
       </span>
       pronunciation of the letter ⟨j⟩ and—in a large part of Spain—the characteristic interdental
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [θ]
       </span>
       ("th-sound") for the letter ⟨z⟩ (and for ⟨c⟩ before ⟨e⟩ or ⟨i⟩). See
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_Spanish#Modern_development_of_the_Old_Spanish_sibilants" title="History of Spanish">
        History of Spanish (Modern development of the Old Spanish sibilants)
       </a>
       for details.
      </p>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Gram%C3%A1tica_de_la_lengua_castellana" title="Gramática de la lengua castellana">
           Gramática de la lengua castellana
          </a>
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , written in
       <a href="/wiki/Salamanca" title="Salamanca">
        Salamanca
       </a>
       in 1492 by
       <a href="/wiki/Antonio_de_Nebrija" title="Antonio de Nebrija">
        Elio Antonio de Nebrija
       </a>
       , was the first grammar written for a modern European language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35">
        <a href="#cite_note-35">
         [35]
        </a>
       </sup>
       According to a popular anecdote, when Nebrija presented it to
       <a href="/wiki/Isabella_I_of_Castile" title="Isabella I of Castile">
        Queen Isabella I
       </a>
       , she asked him what was the use of such a work, and he answered that language is the instrument of empire.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
        <a href="#cite_note-36">
         [36]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In his introduction to the grammar, dated 18 August 1492, Nebrija wrote that "... language was always the companion of empire."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37">
        <a href="#cite_note-37">
         [37]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       From the sixteenth century onwards, the language was taken to
       <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
        America
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">
        Spanish East Indies
       </a>
       via
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">
        Spanish colonization of America
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes_Saavedra" title="Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra">
        Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra
       </a>
       , author of
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Don_Quixote" title="Don Quixote">
         Don Quixote
        </a>
       </i>
       , is such a well-known reference in the world that Spanish is often called
       <i>
        la lengua de Cervantes
       </i>
       ("the language of Cervantes").
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
        <a href="#cite_note-38">
         [38]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In the twentieth century, Spanish was introduced to
       <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">
        Western Sahara
       </a>
       , and to areas of the United States that had not been part of the Spanish Empire, such as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_Harlem" title="Spanish Harlem">
        Spanish Harlem
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
        New York City
       </a>
       . For details on borrowed words and other external influences upon Spanish, see
       <a href="/wiki/Influences_on_the_Spanish_language" title="Influences on the Spanish language">
        Influences on the Spanish language
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Grammar">
        Grammar
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Grammar">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_grammar" title="Spanish grammar">
        Spanish grammar
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1893" data-file-width="1443" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg/170px-Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg/255px-Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg/340px-Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cervantes_J%C3%A1uregui.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Miguel_de_Cervantes" title="Miguel de Cervantes">
          Miguel de Cervantes
         </a>
         considered the greatest figure of Spanish literature in Europe, and author of
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Don_Quixote" title="Don Quixote">
           Don Quixote
          </a>
         </i>
         , considered the first modern European novel.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Most of the grammatical and
       <a href="/wiki/Linguistic_typology" title="Linguistic typology">
        typological
       </a>
       features of Spanish are shared with the other
       <a href="/wiki/Romance_languages" title="Romance languages">
        Romance languages
       </a>
       . Spanish is a
       <a href="/wiki/Fusional_language" title="Fusional language">
        fusional language
       </a>
       . The
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_nouns" title="Spanish nouns">
        noun
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_adjectives" title="Spanish adjectives">
        adjective
       </a>
       systems exhibit two
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
        genders
       </a>
       and two
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
        numbers
       </a>
       , in addition articles and some
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_pronouns" title="Spanish pronouns">
        pronouns
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_determiners" title="Spanish determiners">
        determiners
       </a>
       have a neuter gender in singular. There are about fifty
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_conjugation" title="Grammatical conjugation">
        conjugated
       </a>
       forms per
       <a href="/wiki/Verb" title="Verb">
        verb
       </a>
       , with 3 tenses: past, present, future; 2 aspects for past: perfective, imperfective; 4 moods: indicative, subjunctive, conditional, imperative; 3 persons: first, second, third; 2 numbers: singular, plural; 3
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Verboid" title="Verboid">
        verboid
       </a>
       forms: infinitive, gerund, and past participle. Verbs express
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T-V_distinction" title="T-V distinction">
        T-V distinction
       </a>
       by using different persons for formal and informal addresses. (For a detailed overview of verbs, see
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_verbs" title="Spanish verbs">
        Spanish verbs
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_irregular_verbs" title="Spanish irregular verbs">
        Spanish irregular verbs
       </a>
       .)
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish
       <a href="/wiki/Syntax" title="Syntax">
        syntax
       </a>
       is considered
       <a href="/wiki/Branching_(linguistics)" title="Branching (linguistics)">
        right-branching
       </a>
       , meaning that subordinate or
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_modifier" title="Grammatical modifier">
        modifying
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Constituent_(linguistics)" title="Constituent (linguistics)">
        constituents
       </a>
       tend to be placed after their head words. The language uses
       <a href="/wiki/Preposition_and_postposition" title="Preposition and postposition">
        prepositions
       </a>
       (rather than postpositions or inflection of nouns for
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_case" title="Grammatical case">
        case
       </a>
       ), and usually—though not always—places
       <a href="/wiki/Adjective" title="Adjective">
        adjectives
       </a>
       after
       <a href="/wiki/Noun" title="Noun">
        nouns
       </a>
       , as do most other Romance languages.
      </p>
      <p>
       The language is classified as a
       <a href="/wiki/Subject%E2%80%93verb%E2%80%93object" title="Subject–verb–object">
        subject–verb–object
       </a>
       language; however, as in most Romance languages, constituent order is highly variable and governed mainly by
       <a href="/wiki/Topicalization" title="Topicalization">
        topicalization
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Focus_(linguistics)" title="Focus (linguistics)">
        focus
       </a>
       rather than by syntax. It is a "
       <a href="/wiki/Pro-drop_language" title="Pro-drop language">
        pro-drop
       </a>
       ", or "
       <a href="/wiki/Null-subject_language" title="Null-subject language">
        null-subject
       </a>
       " language—that is, it allows the deletion of subject pronouns when they are
       <a href="/wiki/Pragmatics" title="Pragmatics">
        pragmatically
       </a>
       unnecessary. Spanish is described as a "
       <a href="/wiki/Verb_framing" title="Verb framing">
        verb-framed
       </a>
       " language, meaning that the
       <i>
        direction
       </i>
       of motion is expressed in the verb while the
       <i>
        mode
       </i>
       of locomotion is expressed adverbially (e.g.
       <i>
        subir corriendo
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        salir volando
       </i>
       ; the respective English equivalents of these examples—'to run up' and 'to fly out'—show that English is, by contrast, "satellite-framed", with mode of locomotion expressed in the verb and direction in an adverbial modifier).
      </p>
      <p>
       Subject/verb inversion is not required in questions, and thus the recognition of declarative or interrogative may depend entirely on intonation.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Phonology">
        Phonology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Phonology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <table class="metadata mbox-small noprint selfref" role="presentation" style="background-color:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;color:#000;width: 22em;">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          <img alt="[]" data-file-height="100" data-file-width="75" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/30px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/45px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Parentesi_Quadre.svg/60px-Parentesi_Quadre.svg.png 2x" width="30"/>
         </a>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text plainlist" style="vertical-align:middle; font-size:95%;">
         <b>
          This article contains
          <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
           IPA
          </a>
          phonetic symbols.
         </b>
         Without proper
         <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Fonts" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
          rendering support
         </a>
         , you may see
         <a href="/wiki/Specials_(Unicode_block)#Replacement_character" title="Specials (Unicode block)">
          question marks, boxes, or other symbols
         </a>
         instead of
         <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">
          Unicode
         </a>
         characters. For an introductory guide on IPA symbols, see
         <a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">
          Help:IPA
         </a>
         .
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_phonology" title="Spanish phonology">
        Spanish phonology
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Spanish phonemic system is originally descended from that of
       <a href="/wiki/Vulgar_Latin" title="Vulgar Latin">
        Vulgar Latin
       </a>
       . Its development exhibits some traits in common with the neighboring dialects—especially
       <a href="/wiki/Leonese_dialect" title="Leonese dialect">
        Leonese
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">
        Aragonese
       </a>
       —as well as other traits unique to
       <a href="/wiki/Castilian_Spanish" title="Castilian Spanish">
        Castilian
       </a>
       . Castilian is unique among its neighbors in the aspiration and eventual loss of the Latin initial /f/ sound (e.g. Cast.
       <i>
        harina
       </i>
       vs. Leon. and Arag.
       <i>
        farina
       </i>
       ).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39">
        <a href="#cite_note-39">
         [39]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Latin initial consonant sequences
       <i>
        pl-
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        cl-
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        fl-
       </i>
       in Spanish typically become
       <i>
        ll-
       </i>
       (pronounced [ʎ], [j], [ʝ], [ʒ], or [d͡ʒ]), while in Aragonese they are preserved, and in Leonese they present a variety of outcomes, including [tʃ], [ʃ], and [ʎ]. Where Latin had
       <i>
        -li-
       </i>
       before a vowel (e.g.
       <i>
        filius
       </i>
       ) or the ending
       <i>
        -iculus
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        -icula
       </i>
       (e.g.
       <i>
        auricula
       </i>
       ), Modern Spanish produces the velar fricative [x] (
       <i>
        hijo
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        oreja
       </i>
       , where neighboring languages have the palatal lateral [ʎ] (e.g. Portuguese
       <i>
        filho
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        orelha
       </i>
       ; Catalan
       <i>
        fill
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        orella
       </i>
       ).
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Segmental_phonology">
        Segmental phonology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Segmental phonology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spanish_vowel_chart.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="746" data-file-width="982" height="190" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Spanish_vowel_chart.svg/250px-Spanish_vowel_chart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Spanish_vowel_chart.svg/375px-Spanish_vowel_chart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Spanish_vowel_chart.svg/500px-Spanish_vowel_chart.svg.png 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spanish_vowel_chart.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Spanish vowel chart, from
         <a href="#CITEREFLadefogedJohnson2010">
          Ladefoged &amp; Johnson (2010
         </a>
         :227)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Spanish
       <a href="/wiki/Phoneme" title="Phoneme">
        phonemic
       </a>
       inventory consists of five vowel phonemes (
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /a/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       ) and 17 to 19 consonant phonemes (the exact number depending on the dialect
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40">
        <a href="#cite_note-40">
         [40]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ). The main
       <a href="/wiki/Allophone" title="Allophone">
        allophonic
       </a>
       variation among vowels is the reduction of the high vowels
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /i/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /u/
       </span>
       to glides—
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [j]
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [w]
       </span>
       respectively—when unstressed and adjacent to another vowel. Some instances of the mid vowels
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /e/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /o/
       </span>
       , determined lexically, alternate with the diphthongs
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /je/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /we/
       </span>
       respectively when stressed, in a process that is better described as
       <a href="/wiki/Morphophonology" title="Morphophonology">
        morphophonemic
       </a>
       rather than phonological, as it is not predictable from phonology alone.
      </p>
      <p>
       The Spanish consonant system is characterized by (1) three
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nasal_stop" title="Nasal stop">
        nasal
       </a>
       phonemes, and one or two (depending on the dialect)
       <a href="/wiki/Lateral_consonant" title="Lateral consonant">
        lateral
       </a>
       phoneme(s), which in syllable-final position
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Archiphonemic" title="Archiphonemic">
        lose their contrast
       </a>
       and are subject to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Assimilation_(linguistics)" title="Assimilation (linguistics)">
        assimilation
       </a>
       to a following consonant; (2) three
       <a href="/wiki/Voicelessness" title="Voicelessness">
        voiceless
       </a>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plosive" title="Plosive">
        stops
       </a>
       and the
       <a href="/wiki/Affricate_consonant" title="Affricate consonant">
        affricate
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /tʃ/
       </span>
       ; (3) three or four (depending on the dialect)
       <a href="/wiki/Voicelessness" title="Voicelessness">
        voiceless
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Fricative_consonant" title="Fricative consonant">
        fricatives
       </a>
       ; (4) a set of voiced
       <a href="/wiki/Obstruent" title="Obstruent">
        obstruents
       </a>
       —
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /b/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /d/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɡ/
       </span>
       , and sometimes
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʝ/
       </span>
       —which alternate between
       <a href="/wiki/Approximant_consonant" title="Approximant consonant">
        approximant
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plosive" title="Plosive">
        plosive
       </a>
       allophones depending on the environment; and (5) a phonemic distinction between the "
       <a href="/wiki/Flap_consonant" title="Flap consonant">
        tapped
       </a>
       " and "
       <a href="/wiki/Trill_consonant" title="Trill consonant">
        trilled
       </a>
       "
       <i>
        r
       </i>
       -sounds (single ⟨r⟩ and double ⟨rr⟩ in orthography).
      </p>
      <p>
       In the following table of consonant phonemes,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /θ/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʎ/
       </span>
       are marked with an asterisk (*) to indicate that they are preserved only in some dialects. In most dialects they have been merged, respectively, with
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /s/
       </span>
       and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʝ/
       </span>
       , in the mergers called, respectively,
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceceo" title="Ceceo">
         seseo
        </a>
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ye%C3%ADsmo" title="Yeísmo">
         yeísmo
        </a>
       </i>
       . The phoneme
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʃ/
       </span>
       is in parentheses () to indicate that it appears only in
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Loanwords" title="Loanwords">
        loanwords
       </a>
       . Each of the voiced obstruent phonemes
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /b/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /d/
       </span>
       ,
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ʝ/
       </span>
       , and
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /ɡ/
       </span>
       appears to the right of a
       <i>
        pair
       </i>
       of voiceless phonemes, to indicate that, while the
       <i>
        voiceless
       </i>
       phonemes maintain a phonemic contrast between plosive (or affricate) and fricative, the
       <i>
        voiced
       </i>
       ones alternate
       <a href="/wiki/Allophone" title="Allophone">
        allophonically
       </a>
       (i.e. without phonemic contrast) between plosive and approximant pronunciations.
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto; text-align: center;">

        </td>
        <td rowspan="2" style="border-left:0; width:25px;">

          </a>

          </a>
         </span>
        </td>
        <td rowspan="2" style="border-left:0; width:25px;">

          </a>
         </span>
        </td>
       </tr>

        </td>

          </a>
         </span>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2">
        </td>
