       </tr>
      </table>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Prosody">
        Prosody
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Prosody">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Spanish is classified by its
       <a href="/wiki/Isochrony" title="Isochrony">
        rhythm
       </a>
       as a
       <a href="/wiki/Isochrony#syllable_timing" title="Isochrony">
        syllable-timed language
       </a>
       : each syllable has approximately the same duration regardless of stress.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42">
        <a href="#cite_note-42">
         [42]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43">
        <a href="#cite_note-43">
         [43]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish
       <a href="/wiki/Intonation_(linguistics)" title="Intonation (linguistics)">
        intonation
       </a>
       varies significantly according to dialect but generally conforms to a pattern of falling tone for declarative sentences and wh-questions (who, what, why, etc.) and rising tone for
       <a href="/wiki/Yes%E2%80%93no_question" title="Yes–no question">
        yes/no questions
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
        <a href="#cite_note-44">
         [44]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
        <a href="#cite_note-45">
         [45]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are no syntactic markers to distinguish between questions and statements and thus, the recognition of declarative or interrogative depends entirely on intonation.
      </p>
      <p>
       Stress most often occurs on any of the last three syllables of a word, with some rare exceptions at the fourth-last or earlier syllables. The
       <i>
        tendencies
       </i>
       of stress assignment are as follows:
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
        <a href="#cite_note-46">
         [46]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        In words that end with a vowel, stress most often falls on the penultimate syllable.
       </li>
       <li>
        In words that end with a consonant, stress most often falls on the last syllable, with the following exceptions: The grammatical endings
        <i>
         -n
        </i>
        (for third-person-plural of verbs) and
        <i>
         -s
        </i>
        (whether for plural of nouns and adjectives or for second-person-singular of verbs) do not change the location of stress. Thus, regular
        <i>
         verbs
        </i>
        ending with
        <i>
         -n
        </i>
        and the great majority of words ending with
        <i>
         -s
        </i>
        are stressed on the penult. Although a significant number of nouns and adjectives ending with
        <i>
         -n
        </i>
        are also stressed on the penult (
        <i>
         joven
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         virgen
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         mitin
        </i>
        ), the great majority of nouns and adjectives ending with
        <i>
         -n
        </i>
        are stressed on their last syllable (
        <i>
         capitán
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         almacén
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         jardín
        </i>
        ,
        <i>
         corazón
        </i>
        ).
       </li>
       <li>
        Preantepenultimate stress (stress on the fourth-to-last syllable) occurs rarely, only on verbs with
        <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
         clitic
        </a>
        pronouns attached (
        <i>
         guardándoselos
        </i>
        'saving them for him/her/them/you').
       </li>
      </ul>
      <p>
       In addition to the many exceptions to these tendencies, there are numerous
       <a href="/wiki/Minimal_pair" title="Minimal pair">
        minimal pairs
       </a>
       that contrast solely on stress such as
       <i>
        sábana
       </i>
       ('sheet') and
       <i>
        sabana
       </i>
       ('savannah');
       <i>
        límite
       </i>
       ('boundary'),
       <i>
        limite
       </i>
       ('[that] he/she limits') and
       <i>
        limité
       </i>
       ('I limited');
       <i>
        líquido
       </i>
       ('liquid'),
       <i>
        liquido
       </i>
       ('I sell off') and
       <i>
        liquidó
       </i>
       ('he/she sold off').
      </p>
      <p>
       The orthographic system unambiguously reflects where the stress occurs: in the absence of an accent mark, the stress falls on the last syllable unless the last letter is ⟨n⟩, ⟨s⟩, or a vowel, in which cases the stress falls on the next-to-last (penultimate) syllable. Exceptions to those rules are indicated by an acute accent mark over the vowel of the stressed syllable. (See
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_orthography" title="Spanish orthography">
        Spanish orthography
       </a>
       .)
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Geographical_distribution">
        Geographical distribution
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Geographical distribution">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Hispanophone" title="Hispanophone">
        Hispanophone
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="center">
       <div class="thumb tnone">
        <div class="thumbinner" style="width:502px;">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Study_of_spanish.svg">
          <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="415" data-file-width="940" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Study_of_spanish.svg/500px-Study_of_spanish.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Study_of_spanish.svg/750px-Study_of_spanish.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Study_of_spanish.svg/1000px-Study_of_spanish.svg.png 2x" width="500"/>
         </a>
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <div class="magnify">
           <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Study_of_spanish.svg" title="Enlarge">
           </a>
          </div>
          <table>
           <tr>
            <td>
             <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
              <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #800000; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
              </span>
              Official or co-official language
             </div>
            </td>
            <td>
             <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
              <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #D40000; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
              </span>
              1,000,000+
             </div>
            </td>
            <td>
             <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
              <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FF8080; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
              </span>
              100,000+
             </div>
            </td>
            <td>
             <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
              <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFD5D5; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
              </span>
              20,000+
             </div>
            </td>
           </tr>
          </table>
          <center>
           Active learning of Spanish.
           <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
            <a href="#cite_note-47">
             [47]
            </a>
           </sup>
          </center>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Spanish is the primary language of 20 countries worldwide. It is estimated that the combined total number of Spanish speakers is between 470 and 500 million, making it the second most widely spoken language in terms of native speakers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nationsonline_48-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-nationsonline-48">
         [48]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49">
        <a href="#cite_note-49">
         [49]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is the third most spoken language by total number of speakers (after
       <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">
        Mandarin
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        English
       </a>
       ).
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_used_on_the_Internet" title="Languages used on the Internet">
        Internet usage
       </a>
       statistics for 2007 also show Spanish as the third most commonly used language on the Internet, after
       <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
        English
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Mandarin_Chinese" title="Mandarin Chinese">
        Mandarin
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50">
        <a href="#cite_note-50">
         [50]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Europe">
        Europe
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Europe">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">
        Peninsular Spanish
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="570" height="232" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg/220px-Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg/330px-Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg/440px-Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Knowledge_of_Spanish_in_European_Union.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Percentage of people who self reportedly know enough Spanish to hold a conversation, in the EU, 2005
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #554400; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Native country
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #AA8800; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          More than 8.99%
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #E5B700; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Between 4% and 8.99%
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFDD55; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Between 1% and 3.99%
         </div>
         <div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column">
          <span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFEEAA; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">
          </span>
          Less than 1%
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In
       <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">
        Europe
       </a>
       , Spanish is an official language of Spain, the country after which it is named and from which it originated. It is widely spoken in
       <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">
        Gibraltar
       </a>
       , although English is the official, international language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51">
        <a href="#cite_note-51">
         [51]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It is also commonly spoken in
       <a href="/wiki/Andorra" title="Andorra">
        Andorra
       </a>
       , although
       <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
        Catalan
       </a>
       is the official language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
        <a href="#cite_note-52">
         [52]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is also spoken by small communities in other European countries, such as the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
        United Kingdom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">
        France
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">
        Italy
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">
        Germany
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53">
        <a href="#cite_note-53">
         [53]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Spanish is an official language of the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       . In
       <a href="/wiki/Switzerland" title="Switzerland">
        Switzerland
       </a>
       , which had a massive influx of Spanish migrants in the 20th century, Spanish is the
       <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">
        native language
       </a>
       of 2.2% of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
        <a href="#cite_note-54">
         [54]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Americas">
        Americas
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Americas">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Hispanic_America">
        Hispanic America
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Hispanic America">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Americas" title="Spanish language in the Americas">
        Spanish language in the Americas
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Most Spanish speakers are in
       <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_America" title="Hispanic America">
        Hispanic America
       </a>
       ; of all countries with a majority of Spanish speakers, only
       <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
        Spain
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       are outside the
       <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">
        Americas
       </a>
       . Nationally, Spanish is the official language—either
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">
         de facto
        </a>
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">
         de jure
        </a>
       </i>
       —of
       <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">
        Argentina
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">
        Bolivia
       </a>
       (co-official with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechua_language" title="Quechua language">
        Quechua
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aymara_language" title="Aymara language">
        Aymara
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">
        Guarani
       </a>
       , and 34 other languages),
       <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">
        Chile
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">
        Colombia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">
        Costa Rica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">
        Cuba
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">
        Dominican Republic
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">
        Ecuador
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">
        El Salvador
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">
        Guatemala
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">
        Honduras
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       (co-official with 63 indigenous languages),
       <a href="/wiki/Nicaragua" title="Nicaragua">
        Nicaragua
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">
        Panama
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">
        Paraguay
       </a>
       (co-official with
       <a href="/wiki/Guarani_language" title="Guarani language">
        Guaraní
       </a>
       ),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55">
        <a href="#cite_note-55">
         [55]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">
        Peru
       </a>
       (co-official with
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quechua_language" title="Quechua language">
        Quechua
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aymara_language" title="Aymara language">
        Aymara
       </a>
       , and "the other indigenous languages"
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56">
        <a href="#cite_note-56">
         [56]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ),
       <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rico" title="Puerto Rico">
        Puerto Rico
       </a>
       (co-official with English),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57">
        <a href="#cite_note-57">
         [57]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">
        Uruguay
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">
        Venezuela
       </a>
       . Spanish has no official recognition in the former
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_overseas_territories" title="British overseas territories">
        British colony
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Belize" title="Belize">
        Belize
       </a>
       ; however, per the 2000 census, it is spoken by 43% of the population.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Belizecen_58-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Belizecen-58">
         [58]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
        <a href="#cite_note-59">
         [59]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Mainly, it is spoken by the descendants of Hispanics who have been in the region since the seventeenth century; however, English is the official language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60">
        <a href="#cite_note-60">
         [60]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Due to their proximity to Spanish-speaking countries,
       <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">
        Trinidad and Tobago
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">
        Brazil
       </a>
       have implemented Spanish language teaching into their education systems. The Trinidad government launched the
       <i>
        Spanish as a First Foreign Language
       </i>
       (SAFFL) initiative in March 2005.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
        <a href="#cite_note-61">
         [61]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2005, the
       <a href="/wiki/National_Congress_of_Brazil" title="National Congress of Brazil">
        National Congress of Brazil
       </a>
       approved a bill, signed into law by the
       <a href="/wiki/President_of_Brazil" title="President of Brazil">
        President
       </a>
       , making it mandatory for
       <a href="/wiki/School" title="School">
        schools
       </a>
       to offer Spanish as an alternative foreign language course in both public and private secondary schools in Brazil.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
        <a href="#cite_note-62">
         [62]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In September 2016 this law was revoked by
       <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">
        Michel Temer
       </a>
       after
       <a href="/wiki/Impeachment_of_Dilma_Rousseff" title="Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff">
        impeachment of Dilma Rousseff
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63">
        <a href="#cite_note-63">
         [63]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In many border towns and villages along Paraguay and Uruguay, a
       <a href="/wiki/Mixed_language" title="Mixed language">
        mixed language
       </a>
       known as
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Riverense_Portu%C3%B1ol" title="Riverense Portuñol">
        Portuñol
       </a>
       is spoken.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
        <a href="#cite_note-64">
         [64]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="United_States">
        United States
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: United States">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_United_States" title="Spanish language in the United States">
        Spanish language in the United States
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/New_Mexican_Spanish" title="New Mexican Spanish">
        New Mexican Spanish
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="593" data-file-width="959" height="186" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg/300px-Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg/450px-Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg/600px-Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="300"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spanish_spoken_at_home_in_the_United_States.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Spanish spoken in the United States. Darker shades of green indicate higher percentages of Spanish speakers.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       According to 2006 census data, 44.3 million people of the U.S. population were
       <a href="/wiki/Hispanic" title="Hispanic">
        Hispanic
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_America" title="Hispanic America">
        Hispanic American
       </a>
       by origin;
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
        <a href="#cite_note-65">
         [65]
        </a>
       </sup>
       38.3 million people, 13 percent, of the population over five years old speak Spanish at home.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US_Spanish_66-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-US_Spanish-66">
         [66]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The Spanish language has a long history of presence in the United States due to early Spanish and, later, Mexican administration over territories now forming the
       <a href="/wiki/Southwestern_United_States" title="Southwestern United States">
        southwestern states
       </a>
       , as well as
       <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">
        Florida
       </a>
       , which was Spanish territory until 1821.
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is by far the most common second language spoken and taught in the country, and with over 50 million total speakers, the United States is now the second largest Spanish-speaking country in the world after Mexico.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Más_'speak_spanish'_que_en_España_67-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Más_'speak_spanish'_que_en_España-67">
         [67]
        </a>
       </sup>
       While English is the de facto national language of the country, Spanish is often used in public services and notices at the federal and state levels. Spanish is also used in administration in the state of
       <a href="/wiki/New_Mexico" title="New Mexico">
        New Mexico
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68">
        <a href="#cite_note-68">
         [68]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The language also has a strong influence in major metropolitan areas such as those of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Los_Angeles_area" title="Greater Los Angeles area">
        Los Angeles
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Miami_metropolitan_area" title="Miami metropolitan area">
        Miami
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/San_Antonio_metropolitan_area" title="San Antonio metropolitan area">
        San Antonio
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">
        New York
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area" title="San Francisco Bay Area">
        San Francisco
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Dallas%E2%80%93Fort_Worth_metroplex" title="Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex">
        Dallas
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Phoenix_metropolitan_area" title="Phoenix metropolitan area">
        Phoenix
       </a>
       ; as well as more recently,
       <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">
        Chicago
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley" title="Las Vegas Valley">
        Las Vegas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Boston" title="Greater Boston">
        Boston
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Denver" title="Greater Denver">
        Denver
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Houston" title="Greater Houston">
        Houston
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Indianapolis" title="Greater Indianapolis">
        Indianapolis
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Philadelphia" title="Greater Philadelphia">
        Philadelphia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Cleveland" title="Greater Cleveland">
        Cleveland
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Salt_Lake_City" title="Greater Salt Lake City">
        Salt Lake City
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Atlanta" title="Greater Atlanta">
        Atlanta
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Nashville" title="Greater Nashville">
        Nashville
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Greater_Orlando" title="Greater Orlando">
        Orlando
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Tampa" title="Greater Tampa">
        Tampa
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greater_Raleigh" title="Greater Raleigh">
        Raleigh
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington_metropolitan_area" title="Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area">
        Baltimore-Washington, D.C.
       </a>
       due to 20th- and 21st-century immigration.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Africa">
        Africa
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Africa">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Equatoguinean_Spanish" title="Equatoguinean Spanish">
        Equatoguinean Spanish
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:142px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Donato_ndongo.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="185" data-file-width="140" height="185" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/3/36/Donato_ndongo.jpg" width="140"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Donato_ndongo.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a href="/wiki/Donato_Ndongo-Bidyogo" title="Donato Ndongo-Bidyogo">
          Donato Ndongo-Bidyogo
         </a>
         , writer, poet, journalist and promoter of the Spanish language.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni,_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni%2C_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg/220px-Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni%2C_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni%2C_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg/330px-Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni%2C_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni%2C_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg/440px-Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni%2C_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Museo_de_la_Guerra_en_Rabuni,_sede_del_gobierno_de_la_RASD.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Bilingual signage of
         <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Liberation_Army_Museum" title="People's Liberation Army Museum">
          Museum of the Sahrawi People's Liberation Army
         </a>
         in Western Sahara written in Spanish and Arabic.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       In
       <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">
        Africa
       </a>
       , Spanish is official (along with Portuguese and French) in
       <a href="/wiki/Equatorial_Guinea" title="Equatorial Guinea">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       , as well as an official language of the
       <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">
        African Union
       </a>
       . In Equatorial Guinea, Spanish is the predominant language when native and non-native speakers (around 500,000 people) are counted, while
       <a href="/wiki/Fang_language" title="Fang language">
        Fang
       </a>
       is the most spoken language by number of native speakers.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69">
        <a href="#cite_note-69">
         [69]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70">
        <a href="#cite_note-70">
         [70]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish is also spoken in the integral territories of Spain in North Africa, which include the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Autonomous_cities_of_Spain" title="Autonomous cities of Spain">
        Spanish cities
       </a>
       of
       <a href="/wiki/Ceuta" title="Ceuta">
        Ceuta
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Melilla" title="Melilla">
        Melilla
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Plazas_de_soberan%C3%ADa" title="Plazas de soberanía">
        Plazas de soberanía
       </a>
       , and the
       <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">
        Canary Islands
       </a>
       archipelago (population 2,000,000), located some 100 km off the northwest coast of mainland Africa.
      </p>
      <p>
       Within Northern
       <a href="/wiki/Morocco" title="Morocco">
        Morocco
       </a>
       , a former
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_Morocco#European_influence" title="History of Morocco">
        Spanish protectorate
       </a>
       that is also geographically close to Spain, approximately 20,000 people speak
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_as_a_second_language" title="Spanish as a second language">
        Spanish as a second language
       </a>
       , while Arabic is the
       <i>
        de jure
       </i>
       official language. A small number of Moroccan Jews also speak the Sephardic Spanish dialect
       <a href="/wiki/Haketia" title="Haketia">
        Haketia
       </a>
       (related to the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ladino_language" title="Ladino language">
        Ladino
       </a>
       dialect spoken in
       <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">
        Israel
       </a>
       ). Spanish is spoken by some small communities in
       <a href="/wiki/Angola" title="Angola">
        Angola
       </a>
       because of the Cuban influence from the
       <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">
        Cold War
       </a>
       and in
       <a href="/wiki/South_Sudan" title="South Sudan">
        South Sudan
       </a>
       among South Sudanese natives that relocated to Cuba during the Sudanese wars and returned in time for their country's independence.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71">
        <a href="#cite_note-71">
         [71]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In
       <a href="/wiki/Western_Sahara" title="Western Sahara">
        Western Sahara
       </a>
       , formerly
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Sahara" title="Spanish Sahara">
        Spanish Sahara
       </a>
       , Spanish was officially spoken during the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Today, Spanish in this disputed territory is maintained by populations of Sahrawi nomads numbering about 500,000 people, and is de facto official alongside Arabic in the
       <a href="/wiki/Sahrawi_Arab_Democratic_Republic" title="Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic">
        Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic
       </a>
       , although this entity receives limited international recognition.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72">
        <a href="#cite_note-72">
         [72]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
        <a href="#cite_note-73">
         [73]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Asia-Pacific">
        Asia-Pacific
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Asia-Pacific">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       See also:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Philippines" title="Spanish language in the Philippines">
        Spanish language in the Philippines
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:263px;max-width:263px">
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:127px;max-width:127px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La-solidaridad2.jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="367" data-file-width="264" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/La-solidaridad2.jpg/125px-La-solidaridad2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/La-solidaridad2.jpg/188px-La-solidaridad2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/La-solidaridad2.jpg/250px-La-solidaridad2.jpg 2x" width="125"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:132px;max-width:132px">
         <div class="thumbimage">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:La_Illustracion_Filipina_(1892).jpg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="545" height="172" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/La_Illustracion_Filipina_%281892%29.jpg/130px-La_Illustracion_Filipina_%281892%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/La_Illustracion_Filipina_%281892%29.jpg/195px-La_Illustracion_Filipina_%281892%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/La_Illustracion_Filipina_%281892%29.jpg/260px-La_Illustracion_Filipina_%281892%29.jpg 2x" width="130"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div style="clear:left">
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">
         <i>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La_Solidaridad" title="La Solidaridad">
           La Solidaridad
          </a>
         </i>
         newspaper and
         <a href="/wiki/Juan_Luna" title="Juan Luna">
          Juan Luna
         </a>
         (a Filipino
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Ilustrado" title="Ilustrado">
           Ilustrado
          </a>
         </i>
         ).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Spanish is present on
       <a href="/wiki/Easter_Island" title="Easter Island">
        Easter Island
       </a>
       , as it was annexed as a Chilean province in 1888.
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish was an official language of the
       <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">
        Philippines
       </a>
       from the beginning of Spanish rule in 1565 to a constitutional change in 1973. During
       <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Philippines_(1521%E2%80%931898)" title="History of the Philippines (1521–1898)">
        Spanish colonization
       </a>
       (1565–1898), it was the language of government, trade and education, and spoken as a first language by Spaniards and educated Filipinos. In the mid-nineteenth century, the colonial government set up a free public education system with Spanish as the medium of instruction. This increased use of Spanish throughout the islands led to the formation of a class of Spanish-speaking intellectuals called the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ilustrados" title="Ilustrados">
         Ilustrados
        </a>
       </i>
       . Until the Philippine independence in 1898, Spanish was spoken by around 10% of the population as their first and only language. Around 60% of the population spoke Spanish as their second or third language, that makes a total of 70%.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
        <a href="#cite_note-74">
         [74]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Despite American administration after the defeat of Spain in the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War" title="Spanish–American War">
        Spanish–American War
       </a>
       in 1898, the usage of Spanish continued in Philippine literature and press during the early years of American rule. Gradually, however, the American government began increasingly promoting the use of English, and it characterized Spanish as a negative influence of the past. Eventually, by the 1920s, English became the primary language of administration and education.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
        <a href="#cite_note-75">
         [75]
        </a>
       </sup>
       But despite a significant decrease in influence and speakers, Spanish remained an official language of the Philippines when it became independent in 1946, alongside English and
       <a href="/wiki/Filipino_language" title="Filipino language">
        Filipino
       </a>
       , a standardized version of
       <a href="/wiki/Tagalog_language" title="Tagalog language">
        Tagalog
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bandera_03.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="510" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Bandera_03.jpg/250px-Bandera_03.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Bandera_03.jpg/375px-Bandera_03.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Bandera_03.jpg/500px-Bandera_03.jpg 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bandera_03.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Early flag of the
         <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Revolutionary_Army" title="Philippine Revolutionary Army">
          Filipino revolutionaries
         </a>
         ("Long live the Philippine Republic!"). The first two constitutions were written in Spanish.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Spanish was removed from official status in 1973 under the administration of
       <a href="/wiki/Ferdinand_Marcos" title="Ferdinand Marcos">
        Ferdinand Marcos
       </a>
       , but regained its status as an official language two months later under Presidential Decree No. 155, dated 15 March 1973.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76">
        <a href="#cite_note-76">
         [76]
        </a>
       </sup>
       It remained an official language until 1987, with the ratification of the present constitution, in which it was re-designated as a voluntary and optional auxiliary language.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77">
        <a href="#cite_note-77">
         [77]
        </a>
       </sup>
       In 2010, President
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gloria_Macapagal-Arroyo" title="Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo">
        Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo
       </a>
       encouraged the reintroduction of Spanish-language teaching in the Philippine education system.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78">
        <a href="#cite_note-78">
         [78]
        </a>
       </sup>
       But by 2012, the number of secondary schools at which the language was either a compulsory subject or an elective had become very limited.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79">
        <a href="#cite_note-79">
         [79]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Today, despite government promotions of Spanish, less than 0.5% of the population report being able to speak the language proficiently.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80">
        <a href="#cite_note-80">
         [80]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Aside from standard Spanish, a Spanish-based creole language—
       <a href="/wiki/Chavacano" title="Chavacano">
        Chavacano
       </a>
       —developed in the southern Philippines. The number of Chavacano-speakers was estimated at 1.2 million in 1996. However, it is not mutually intelligible with Spanish.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81">
        <a href="#cite_note-81">
         [81]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Speakers of the Zamboangueño variety of Chavacano were numbered about 360,000 in the 2000 census.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82">
        <a href="#cite_note-82">
         [82]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The local
       <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Philippines" title="Languages of the Philippines">
        languages of the Philippines
       </a>
       also retain some Spanish influence, with many words being derived from
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">
        Mexican Spanish
       </a>
       , owing to the control of the islands by Spain through
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico_City" title="Mexico City">
        Mexico City
       </a>
       until 1821, and then directly from Madrid until 1898.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83">
        <a href="#cite_note-83">
         [83]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84">
        <a href="#cite_note-84">
         [84]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Spanish was also used by the colonial governments and educated classes in the former
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_East_Indies" title="Spanish East Indies">
        Spanish East Indies
       </a>
       , consisting of modern-day
       <a href="/wiki/Guam" title="Guam">
        Guam
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands" title="Northern Mariana Islands">
        Northern Mariana Islands
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Palau" title="Palau">
        Palau
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Federated_States_of_Micronesia" title="Federated States of Micronesia">
        Micronesia
       </a>
       , in addition to the Philippines. Spanish loan words are present in the local languages of these territories as a legacy of colonial rule.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85">
        <a href="#cite_note-85">
         [85]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86">
        <a href="#cite_note-86">
         [86]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Today, Spanish is not spoken officially in any of these former Spanish territories. In Guam it is spoken by Catholic people and Puerto Ricans.
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
          <span title="Quotation needed from source to verify. (February 2018)">
           need quotation to verify
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">
        Judaeo-Spanish
       </a>
       was initially spoken by the
       <a href="/wiki/Sephardic_Jews_in_India" title="Sephardic Jews in India">
        Sephardic Jewish community in India
       </a>
       , but was later replaced with
       <a href="/wiki/Judeo-Malayalam" title="Judeo-Malayalam">
        Judeo-Malayalam
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">
        [
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
          <span title="Quotation needed from source to verify. (February 2018)">
           need quotation to verify
          </span>
         </a>
        </i>
        ]
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Spanish_speakers_by_country">
        Spanish speakers by country
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Spanish speakers by country">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The following table shows the number of Spanish speakers in some 79 countries.
      </p>
      <table class="wikitable sortable">
       <tr>
        <th style="width:18%;">
         Country
        </th>
        <th data-sort-type="number" style="width:12%;">
         Population
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_2015_estimate_87-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-UN_2015_estimate-87">
           [87]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </th>
        <th data-sort-type="number" style="width:16%;">
         Spanish as a native language speakers
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88">
          <a href="#cite_note-88">
           [88]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </th>
        <th data-sort-type="number" style="width:14%;">
         Native speakers or very good speakers as a second language
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurob2012_89-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Eurob2012-89">
           [89]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </th>
        <th data-sort-type="number" style="width:14%;">
         Total number of Spanish speakers
         <small>
          (including limited competence speakers)
         </small>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurob2012_89-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-Eurob2012-89">
           [89]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SpanishStudents_90-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-SpanishStudents-90">
           [90]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DemografíaLengEsp_91-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-DemografíaLengEsp-91">
           [91]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr style="background:#efefef;">
        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="840" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/35px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Mexico.svg/46px-Flag_of_Mexico.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>
         <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
          Mexico
         </a>
        </td>
        <td>
         124,737,789
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92">
          <a href="#cite_note-92">
           [92]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
        <td>
         115,631,930 (92.7%)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93">
          <a href="#cite_note-93">
           [93]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
        <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;">
         122,866,722 (98.5%)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DemografíaLengEsp_91-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-DemografíaLengEsp-91">
           [91]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr style="background:#fff;">
        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">

         </sup>
         of 660,400
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eurobarometer_2012_population_133-39">
          <a href="#cite_note-Eurobarometer_2012_population-133">
           [133]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr style="background:#fff;">
        <td>
         <span class="flagicon">
          <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1350" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/23px-Flag_of_India.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/35px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/45px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
         </span>

      </table>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Dialectal_variation">
        Dialectal variation
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Dialectal variation">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:452px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2753" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png/450px-Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png/675px-Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png/900px-Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png 2x" width="450"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Variedades_principales_del_espa%C3%B1ol.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         A world map attempting to identify the main dialects of Spanish.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_dialects_and_varieties" title="Spanish dialects and varieties">
        Spanish dialects and varieties
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       There are important variations (
       <a href="/wiki/Phonology" title="Phonology">
        phonological
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Grammar" title="Grammar">
        grammatical
       </a>
       , and
       <a href="/wiki/Lexicon" title="Lexicon">
        lexical
       </a>
       ) in the spoken Spanish of the various regions of Spain and throughout the Spanish-speaking areas of the Americas.
      </p>
      <p>
       The variety with the most speakers is
       <a href="/wiki/Mexican_Spanish" title="Mexican Spanish">
        Mexican Spanish
       </a>
       . It is spoken by more than twenty percent of the world's Spanish speakers (more than 112 million of the total of more than 500 million, according to the table above). One of its main features is the
       <a href="/wiki/Vowel_reduction" title="Vowel reduction">
        reduction
       </a>
       or loss of
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unstressed_vowel" title="Unstressed vowel">
        unstressed vowels
       </a>
       , mainly when they are in contact with the sound /s/.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
        <a href="#cite_note-228">
         [228]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229">
        <a href="#cite_note-229">
         [229]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In Spain, northern dialects are popularly thought of as closer to the standard, although positive attitudes toward southern dialects have increased significantly in the last 50 years. Even so, the speech of Madrid, which has typically southern features such as
       <a href="/wiki/Ye%C3%ADsmo" title="Yeísmo">
        yeísmo
       </a>
       and s-aspiration, is the standard variety for use on radio and television.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230">
        <a href="#cite_note-230">
         [230]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231">
        <a href="#cite_note-231">
         [231]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
        <a href="#cite_note-232">
         [232]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
        <a href="#cite_note-233">
         [233]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The educated Madrid variety has most influenced the written standard for Spanish.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234">
        <a href="#cite_note-234">
         [234]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Phonology_2">
        Phonology
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Phonology">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The four main phonological divisions are based respectively on (1) the phoneme
       <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_dental_fricative" title="Voiceless dental fricative">
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /θ/
        </span>
       </a>
       ("theta"), (2) the
       <a href="/wiki/Debuccalization" title="Debuccalization">
        debuccalization
       </a>
       of syllable-final
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /s/
       </span>
       , (3) the sound of the spelled ⟨s⟩, (4) and the phoneme
       <a href="/wiki/Palatal_lateral_approximant" title="Palatal lateral approximant">
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʎ/
        </span>
       </a>
       ("turned
       <i>
        y
       </i>
       "),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235">
        <a href="#cite_note-235">
         [235]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The phoneme
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /θ/
        </span>
        (spelled
        <i>
         c
        </i>
        before
        <i>
         e
        </i>
        or
        <i>
         i
        </i>
        and spelled ⟨z⟩ elsewhere), a
        <a href="/wiki/Voiceless_dental_fricative" title="Voiceless dental fricative">
         voiceless dental fricative
        </a>
        as in English
        <i>
         <b>
          th
         </b>
         ing
        </i>
        , is maintained by a majority of Spain's population, especially in the northern and central parts of the country. In other areas (some parts of southern Spain, the
        <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">
         Canary Islands
        </a>
        , and the Americas),
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /θ/
        </span>
        is merged with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /s/
        </span>
        . The maintenance of phonemic contrast is called
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Distinci%C3%B3n" title="Distinción">
          distinción
         </a>
        </i>
        in Spanish, while the merger is generally called
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seseo" title="Seseo">
          seseo
         </a>
        </i>
        (in reference to the usual realization of the merged phoneme as
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [s]
        </span>
        ) or, occasionally,
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ceceo" title="Ceceo">
          ceceo
         </a>
        </i>
        (referring to its interdental realization,
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [θ]
        </span>
        , in some parts of southern Spain). In most of Hispanic America, the spelled ⟨c⟩ before ⟨e⟩ or ⟨i⟩, and spelled ⟨z⟩ is always pronounced as a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_sibilant#Dentalized_laminal_alveolar" title="Voiceless alveolar sibilant">
         voiceless alveolar "hissing" sibilant
        </a>
        .
       </li>
       <li>
        The debuccalization (pronunciation as
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [h]
        </span>
        , or loss) of syllable-final
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /s/
        </span>
        is associated with the southern half of Spain and lowland Americas: Central America (except central Costa Rica and Guatemala), the Caribbean, coastal areas of southern Mexico, and South America except Andean highlands. Debuccalization is frequently called "aspiration" in English, and
        <i>
         aspiración
        </i>
        in Spanish. When there is no debuccalization, the syllable-final
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /s/
        </span>
        is pronounced as
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_sibilant#Retracted_alveolar" title="Voiceless alveolar sibilant">
         voiceless "apico-alveolar" "grave" sibilant
        </a>
        or as a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_sibilant#Dentalized_laminal_alveolar" title="Voiceless alveolar sibilant">
         voiceless alveolar "hissing" sibilant
        </a>
        in the same fashion as in the next paragraph.
       </li>
      </ul>
      <ul>
       <li>
        The sound that corresponds to the letter ⟨s⟩ is pronounced in most of Spain as a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_sibilant#Retracted_alveolar" title="Voiceless alveolar sibilant">
         voiceless "apico-alveolar" sibilant
        </a>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [s̺]
        </span>
        (also described acoustically as "
        <a href="/wiki/Grave_and_acute" title="Grave and acute">
         grave
        </a>
        " and articulatorily as "retracted"), with a weak "hushing" sound reminiscent of
        <a href="/wiki/Retroflex_consonant" title="Retroflex consonant">
         retroflex
        </a>
        fricatives. In most of Hispanic America (except in the
        <a href="/wiki/Colombian_Spanish#Paisa_dialect" title="Colombian Spanish">
         Paisa region
        </a>
        of Colombia) it is pronounced as a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_sibilant#Dentalized_laminal_alveolar" title="Voiceless alveolar sibilant">
         voiceless alveolar
         <i>
          hissing
         </i>
         sibilant
        </a>
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [s]
        </span>
        , much like the most frequent pronunciation of the /s/ of English. Because /s/ is one of the most frequent phonemes in Spanish, the difference of pronunciation is one of the first to be noted by a Spanish-speaking person to differentiate Spaniards from Spanish-speakers of the Americas.
        <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
         [
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
           <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2017)">
            citation needed
           </span>
          </a>
         </i>
         ]
        </sup>
       </li>
       <li>
        The phoneme
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʎ/
        </span>
        spelled ⟨ll⟩,
        <a href="/wiki/Palatal_lateral_approximant" title="Palatal lateral approximant">
         palatal lateral
        </a>
        consonant sometimes compared in sound to the sound of the ⟨lli⟩ of English
        <i>
         million
        </i>
        , tends to be maintained in less-urbanized areas of northern Spain and in
        <a href="/wiki/Andean_Spanish" title="Andean Spanish">
         highland areas of South America
        </a>
        . Meanwhile, in the speech of most other Spanish-speakers, it is merged with
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /ʝ/
        </span>
        ("curly-tail
        <i>
         j
        </i>
        "), a non-lateral, usually voiced, usually fricative, palatal consonant, sometimes compared to English
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         /j/
        </span>
        (
        <i>
         yod
        </i>
        ) as in
        <i>
         <b>
          y
         </b>
         acht
        </i>
        and spelled ⟨y⟩ in Spanish. As with other forms of allophony across world languages, the small difference of the spelled ⟨ll⟩ and the spelled ⟨y⟩ is usually not perceived (the difference is not heard) by people who do not produce them as different phonemes. Such a phonemic merger is called
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Ye%C3%ADsmo" title="Yeísmo">
          yeísmo
         </a>
        </i>
        in Spanish. In
        <a href="/wiki/Rioplatense_Spanish" title="Rioplatense Spanish">
         Rioplatense Spanish
        </a>
        , the merged phoneme is generally pronounced as a postalveolar fricative, either voiced
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ʒ]
        </span>
        (as in English
        <i>
         measure
        </i>
        or the French ⟨j⟩) in the central and western parts of the dialectal region (
        <i>
         <span lang="es">
          <i>
           zheísmo
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        ), or voiceless
        <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
         [ʃ]
        </span>
        (as in the French ⟨ch⟩ or Portuguese ⟨x⟩) in and around Buenos Aires and Montevideo (
        <i>
         <span lang="es">
          <i>
           sheísmo
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        ).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
         <a href="#cite_note-236">
          [236]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </li>
      </ul>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Grammar_2">
        Grammar
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Grammar">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       The main grammatical variations between dialects of Spanish involve differing uses of pronouns, especially those of the second
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">
        person
       </a>
       and, to a lesser extent, the
       <a href="/wiki/Object_pronoun" title="Object pronoun">
        object pronouns
       </a>
       of the third
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">
        person
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Voseo">
        Voseo
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Voseo">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">
        Voseo
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tr>
        <td class="mbox-image">
         <div style="width:52px">
          <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg">
           <img alt="" data-file-height="399" data-file-width="512" height="39" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" width="50"/>
          </a>
         </div>
        </td>
        <td class="mbox-text">
         <div class="mbox-text-span">
          This section
          <b>
           needs additional citations for
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">
            verification
           </a>
          </b>
          .
          <span class="hide-when-compact">
           Please help
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit">
            improve this article
           </a>
           by
           <a href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">
            adding citations to reliable sources
           </a>
           . Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.
          </span>
          <small>
           <i>
            (October 2012)
           </i>
          </small>
          <small class="hide-when-compact">
           <i>
            (
            <a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">
             Learn how and when to remove this template message
            </a>
            )
           </i>
          </small>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Voseo-extension-real.PNG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="922" data-file-width="694" height="332" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Voseo-extension-real.PNG/250px-Voseo-extension-real.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Voseo-extension-real.PNG/375px-Voseo-extension-real.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Voseo-extension-real.PNG/500px-Voseo-extension-real.PNG 2x" width="250"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Voseo-extension-real.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         An examination of the dominance and stress of the voseo dialect in Hispanic America. Data generated as illustrated by the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_of_Spanish_Language_Academies" title="Association of Spanish Language Academies">
          Association of Spanish Language Academies
         </a>
         . The darker the area, the stronger its dominance.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Virtually all dialects of Spanish make the
       <a href="/wiki/T%E2%80%93V_distinction" title="T–V distinction">
        distinction
       </a>
       between a formal and a familiar
       <a href="/wiki/Register_(sociolinguistics)" title="Register (sociolinguistics)">
        register
       </a>
       in the
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_person" title="Grammatical person">
        second-person
       </a>
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_number" title="Grammatical number">
        singular
       </a>
       and thus have two different
       <a href="/wiki/Pronoun" title="Pronoun">
        pronouns
       </a>
       meaning "you":
       <i>
        usted
       </i>
       in the formal and either
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       in the familiar (and each of these three pronouns has its associated verb forms), with the choice of
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       varying from one dialect to another. The use of
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       (and/or its verb forms) is called
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Voseo" title="Voseo">
         voseo
        </a>
       </i>
       . In a few dialects, all three pronouns are used, with
       <i>
        usted
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       denoting respectively formality, familiarity, and intimacy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rae.es_site_237-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-rae.es_site-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       In
       <i>
        voseo
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          vos
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       is the
       <a href="/wiki/Subject_(grammar)" title="Subject (grammar)">
        subject
       </a>
       form (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          vos decís
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , "you say") and the form for the object of a
       <a href="/wiki/Preposition_and_postposition" title="Preposition and postposition">
        preposition
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        voy con vos
       </i>
       , "I am going with you"), while the direct and indirect
       <a href="/wiki/Object_(grammar)" title="Object (grammar)">
        object
       </a>
       forms, and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Possessive_adjective" title="Possessive adjective">
        possessives
       </a>
       , are the same as those associated with
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       :
       <i>
        Vos sabés que tus amigos te respetan
       </i>
       ("You know your friends respect you").
      </p>
      <p>
       The verb forms of
       <i>
        general voseo
       </i>
       are the same as those used with
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       except in the present
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_tense" title="Grammatical tense">
        tense
       </a>
       (
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indicative" title="Indicative">
        indicative
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Imperative_mood" title="Imperative mood">
        imperative
       </a>
       ) verbs. The forms for
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       generally can be derived from those of
       <i>
        vosotros
       </i>
       (the traditional second-person familiar
       <i>
        plural
       </i>
       ) by deleting the
       <a href="/wiki/Semivowel" title="Semivowel">
        glide
       </a>
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [i̯]
       </span>
       , or
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /d/
       </span>
       , where it appears in the ending:
       <i>
        vosotros pensá
        <b>
         i
        </b>
        s
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        vos pensás
       </i>
       ;
       <i>
        vosotros volvé
        <b>
         i
        </b>
        s
       </i>
       &gt;
       <i>
        vos volvés
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        pensa
        <b>
         d
        </b>
        !
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        vosotros
       </i>
       ) &gt;
       <i>
        pensá!
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       ),
       <i>
        volve
        <b>
         d
        </b>
        !
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        vosotros
       </i>
       ) &gt;
       <i>
        volvé!
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       ) .
      </p>
      <table cellpadding="5" class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        General voseo
        <small>
         (
         <a href="/wiki/Rioplatense_Spanish" title="Rioplatense Spanish">
          River Plate Spanish
         </a>
         )
        </small>
       </caption>

        </th>

       </tr>

          </b>
         </i>
        </td>

         <i>

         <br/>

          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
