         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvés
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volviste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volvías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volverás
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volverías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           vuelvas
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volvieras
          </b>
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          <b>
           volvieses
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvé
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormís
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormiste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormirás
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormirías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           duermas
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           durmieras
          </b>
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          <b>
           durmieses
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormí
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="8">
         <small>
          The forms in
          <i>
           <b>
            bold
           </b>
          </i>
          coincide with standard
          <i>
           <b>
            tú
           </b>
           -conjugation
          </i>
          .
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       In Chilean
       <i>
        voseo
       </i>
       on the other hand, almost all verb forms are distinct from their standard
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       -forms.
      </p>
      <table cellpadding="5" class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        Chilean voseo
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">
         Indicative
        </th>
        <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;">
         Subjunctive
        </th>
        <th rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;">
         Imperative
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <th>
         Present
        </th>
        <th>
         Simple past
        </th>
        <th>
         Imperfect past
        </th>
        <th>

        </th>
        <th>
         Conditional
        </th>
        <th>
         Present
        </th>
        <th>
         Past
        </th>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          pensáis
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           pensaste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          pensabais
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         '
         <b>
          pensarás'
         </b>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          pensaríais
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          pensís
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          pensarais
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          pensases
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           piensa
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvís
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volviste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvíais
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         '
         <b>
          volverás'
         </b>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volveríais
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volváis
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvierais
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          volvieses
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           vuelve
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormís
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormiste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormíais
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         '
         <b>
          dormirás'
         </b>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormiríais
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          durmáis
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          durmieras
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          durmieses
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           duerme
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="8">
         <small>
          The forms in
          <i>
           <b>
            bold
           </b>
          </i>
          coincide with standard
          <i>
           <b>
            tú
           </b>
           -conjugation
          </i>
          .
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       The use of the pronoun
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       with the verb forms of
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        vos piensas
       </i>
       ) is called "pronominal
       <i>
        voseo
       </i>
       ". Conversely, the use of the verb forms of
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       with the pronoun
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       (
       <i>
        tú pensás
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        tú pensái
       </i>
       ) is called "verbal
       <i>
        voseo
       </i>
       ".
       <br/>
       In Chile, for example,
       <i>
        verbal voseo
       </i>
       is much more common than the actual use of the pronoun
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       , which is usually reserved for highly informal situations.
      </p>
      <p>
       And in Central American
       <i>
        voseo
       </i>
       , one can see even further distinction.
      </p>
      <table cellpadding="5" class="wikitable">
       <caption>
        Central American voseo
       </caption>
       <tr>
        <th colspan="5" style="text-align:center;">

         Subjunctive
        </th>
        <th rowspan="2" style="text-align:center;">
         Imperative
        </th>
       </tr>

        </th>

         Future
        </th>
        <th>
         Conditional
        </th>
        <th>
         Present
        </th>
        <th>
         Past
        </th>
       </tr>

         <br/>
         <i>

          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          pensá
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvés
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volviste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volvías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volverás
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volverías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvás
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           volvieras
          </b>
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          <b>
           volvieses
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          volvé
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormís
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormiste
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormirás
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           dormirías
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          durmás
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          <b>
           durmieras
          </b>
         </i>
         <br/>
         <i>
          <b>
           durmieses
          </b>
         </i>
        </td>
        <td>
         <i>
          dormí
         </i>
        </td>
       </tr>
       <tr>
        <td colspan="8">
         <small>
          The forms in
          <i>
           <b>
            bold
           </b>
          </i>
          coincide with standard
          <i>
           <b>
            tú
           </b>
           -conjugation
          </i>
          .
         </small>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <h5>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Distribution_in_Spanish-speaking_regions_of_the_Americas">
        Distribution in Spanish-speaking regions of the Americas
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Distribution in Spanish-speaking regions of the Americas">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h5>
      <p>
       Although
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          vos
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       is not used in Spain, it occurs in many Spanish-speaking regions of the Americas as the primary spoken form of the second-person singular familiar pronoun, with wide differences in social consideration. Generally, it can be said that there are zones of exclusive use of
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          tuteo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       (the use of
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       ) in the following areas: almost all of
       <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">
        Mexico
       </a>
       , the West Indies,
       <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">
        Panama
       </a>
       , most of
       <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">
        Colombia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">
        Peru
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela">
        Venezuela
       </a>
       and coastal
       <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">
        Ecuador
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          Tuteo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       as a cultured form alternates with
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          voseo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       as a popular or rural form in
       <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">
        Bolivia
       </a>
       , in the north and south of Peru, in Andean Ecuador, in small zones of the Venezuelan Andes (and most notably in the Venezuelan state of
       <a href="/wiki/Zulia" title="Zulia">
        Zulia
       </a>
       ), and in a large part of Colombia. Some researchers maintain that
       <i>
        voseo
       </i>
       can be heard in some parts of eastern Cuba, and others assert that it is absent from the island.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238">
        <a href="#cite_note-238">
         [238]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          Tuteo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       exists as the second-person usage with an intermediate degree of formality alongside the more familiar
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          voseo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">
        Chile
       </a>
       , in the Venezuelan state of
       <a href="/wiki/Zulia" title="Zulia">
        Zulia
       </a>
       , on the Caribbean coast of
       <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">
        Colombia
       </a>
       , in the
       <a href="/wiki/Azuero_Peninsula" title="Azuero Peninsula">
        Azuero Peninsula
       </a>
       in Panama, in the Mexican state of
       <a href="/wiki/Chiapas" title="Chiapas">
        Chiapas
       </a>
       , and in parts of Guatemala.
      </p>
      <p>
       Areas of generalized
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          voseo
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       include
       <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">
        Argentina
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Nicaragua" title="Nicaragua">
        Nicaragua
       </a>
       , eastern
       <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">
        Bolivia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">
        El Salvador
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">
        Guatemala
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">
        Honduras
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">
        Costa Rica
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Paraguay" title="Paraguay">
        Paraguay
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Uruguay" title="Uruguay">
        Uruguay
       </a>
       and the Colombian departments of
       <a href="/wiki/Antioquia_Department" title="Antioquia Department">
        Antioquia
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Caldas_Department" title="Caldas Department">
        Caldas
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Risaralda_Department" title="Risaralda Department">
        Risaralda
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Quindio" title="Quindio">
        Quindio
       </a>
       and
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Valle_del_Cauca" title="Valle del Cauca">
        Valle del Cauca
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rae.es_site_237-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-rae.es_site-237">
         [237]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Ustedes">
        Ustedes
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Ustedes">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       <i>
        Ustedes
       </i>
       functions as formal and informal second person plural in over 90% of the Spanish-speaking world, including all of Hispanic America, the
       <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">
        Canary Islands
       </a>
       , and some regions of
       <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">
        Andalusia
       </a>
       . In
       <a href="/wiki/Seville" title="Seville">
        Seville
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Huelva" title="Huelva">
        Huelva
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cadiz" title="Cadiz">
        Cadiz
       </a>
       , and other parts of western
       <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">
        Andalusia
       </a>
       , the familiar form is constructed as
       <i>
        ustedes vais
       </i>
       , using the traditional second-person plural form of the verb. Most of Spain maintains the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/T-V_distinction" title="T-V distinction">
        formal/familiar distinction
       </a>
       with
       <i>
        ustedes
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        vosotros
       </i>
       respectively.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Usted">
        Usted
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Usted">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       <i>
        Usted
       </i>
       is the usual second-person singular pronoun in a formal context, but it is used jointly with the third-person singular voice of the verb. It is used to convey respect toward someone who is a generation older or is of higher authority ("you, sir"/"you, ma'am"). It is also used in a
       <i>
        familiar
       </i>
       context by many speakers in Colombia and Costa Rica and in parts of Ecuador and Panama, to the exclusion of
       <i>
        tú
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        vos
       </i>
       . This usage is sometimes called
       <i>
        <a class="extiw" href="https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ustedeo" title="es:Ustedeo">
         ustedeo
        </a>
       </i>
       in Spanish.
      </p>
      <p>
       In Central America, especially in Honduras,
       <i>
        usted
       </i>
       is often used as a formal pronoun to convey respect between the members of a romantic couple.
       <i>
        Usted
       </i>
       is also used that way as well as between parents and children in the Andean regions of Ecuador, Colombia and Venezuela.
      </p>
      <h4>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Third-person_object_pronouns">
        Third-person object pronouns
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Third-person object pronouns">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h4>
      <p>
       Most speakers use (and the
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Real Academia Española">
         Real Academia Española
        </a>
       </i>
       prefers) the pronouns
       <i>
        lo
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        la
       </i>
       for
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_object#The_object_in_linguistics" title="Direct object">
        <i>
         direct
        </i>
        objects
       </a>
       (masculine and feminine respectively, regardless of
       <a href="/wiki/Animacy" title="Animacy">
        animacy
       </a>
       , meaning "him", "her", or "it"), and
       <i>
        le
       </i>
       for
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Direct_object#The_object_in_linguistics" title="Direct object">
        <i>
         indirect
        </i>
        objects
       </a>
       (regardless of
       <a href="/wiki/Grammatical_gender" title="Grammatical gender">
        gender
       </a>
       or
       <a href="/wiki/Animacy" title="Animacy">
        animacy
       </a>
       , meaning "to him", "to her", or "to it"). The usage is sometimes called "etymological", as these direct and indirect object pronouns are a continuation, respectively, of the
       <a href="/wiki/Accusative_case" title="Accusative case">
        accusative
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Dative_case" title="Dative case">
        dative
       </a>
       pronouns of Latin, the ancestor language of Spanish.
      </p>
      <p>
       Deviations from this norm (more common in Spain than in the Americas) are called "
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Le%C3%ADsmo" title="Leísmo">
         leísmo
        </a>
       </i>
       ", "
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Lo%C3%ADsmo" title="Loísmo">
         loísmo
        </a>
       </i>
       ", or "
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/La%C3%ADsmo" title="Laísmo">
         laísmo
        </a>
       </i>
       ", according to which respective pronoun,
       <i>
        le
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        lo
       </i>
       , or
       <i>
        la
       </i>
       , has expanded beyond the etymological usage (
       <i>
        le
       </i>
       as a direct object, or
       <i>
        lo
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        la
       </i>
       as an indirect object).
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Vocabulary">
        Vocabulary
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Vocabulary">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <p>
       Some words can be significantly different in different Hispanophone countries. Most Spanish speakers can recognize other Spanish forms even in places where they are not commonly used, but Spaniards generally do not recognize specifically American usages. For example, Spanish
       <i>
        mantequilla
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        aguacate
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        albaricoque
       </i>
       (respectively, 'butter', 'avocado', 'apricot') correspond to
       <i>
        manteca
       </i>
       (word used for
       <a href="/wiki/Lard" title="Lard">
        lard
       </a>
       in
       <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">
        Peninsular Spanish
       </a>
       ),
       <i>
        palta
       </i>
       , and
       <i>
        damasco
       </i>
       , respectively, in Argentina, Chile (except
       <i>
        manteca
       </i>
       ), Paraguay, Peru (except
       <i>
        manteca
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        damasco
       </i>
       ), and Uruguay.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Relation_to_other_languages">
        Relation to other languages
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Relation to other languages">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Comparison_of_Portuguese_and_Spanish" title="Comparison of Portuguese and Spanish">
        Comparison of Portuguese and Spanish
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Spanish is closely related to the other
       <a href="/wiki/West_Iberian_languages" title="West Iberian languages">
        West Iberian Romance languages
       </a>
       , including
       <a href="/wiki/Asturian_language" title="Asturian language">
        Asturian
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">
        Aragonese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
        Galician
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ladino_language" title="Ladino language">
        Ladino
       </a>
       ,
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leonese_Language" title="Leonese Language">
        Leonese
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Mirandese_language" title="Mirandese language">
        Mirandese
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
        Portuguese
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       It is generally acknowledged that Portuguese- and Spanish-speakers can communicate, although with varying degrees of difficulty.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
        <a href="#cite_note-239">
         [239]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
        <a href="#cite_note-240">
         [240]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
        <a href="#cite_note-241">
         [241]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
        <a href="#cite_note-242">
         [242]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Meanwhile,
       <a href="/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility" title="Mutual intelligibility">
        mutual intelligibility
       </a>
       of the
       <i>
        written
       </i>
       Spanish and Portuguese languages is very high, given that the difficulties of the spoken forms are based more on phonology than on grammatical and lexical dissimilarities.
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">
         Ethnologue
        </a>
       </i>
       gives estimates of the
       <a href="/wiki/Lexical_similarity" title="Lexical similarity">
        lexical similarity
       </a>
       between related languages in terms of precise percentages. For Spanish and Portuguese, that figure is 89%. Italian, on the other hand—although its phonology is more similar to that of Spanish—is said to have a lexical similarity of 82%. Mutual intelligibility between Spanish and
       <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
        French
       </a>
       or between Spanish and
       <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
        Romanian
       </a>
       is lower still, given lexical similarity ratings of 75% and 71% respectively.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnologue_243-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ethnologue-243">
         [243]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ezglot_244-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-ezglot-244">
         [244]
        </a>
       </sup>
       And comprehension of Spanish by French speakers who have not studied the language is much lower, at an estimated 45%. In general, thanks to the common features of the writing systems of the Romance languages, interlingual comprehension of the written word is greater than that of oral communication.
      </p>
      <p>
       The following table compares the forms of some common words in several Romance languages:
      </p>
      <div style="overflow:auto;">
       <table class="wikitable">
        <tr>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">
           Latin
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          Spanish
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">
           Galician
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">
           Portuguese
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Astur-Leonese_linguistic_group" title="Astur-Leonese linguistic group">
           Astur-Leonese
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Aragonese_language" title="Aragonese language">
           Aragonese
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Catalan_language" title="Catalan language">
           Catalan
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
           French
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">
           Italian
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">
           Romanian
          </a>
         </th>
         <th>
          <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">
           English
          </a>
         </th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="la">
            <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
             nos
            </span>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="es">
            <i>
             nosotros
            </i>
            /
            <i>
             nos
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="gl">
            <i>
             nós
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <sup>
           1
          </sup>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="pt">
            <i>
             nós
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <sup>
           1
          </sup>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="ast">
            <i>
             nós
            </i>
            ,
            <i>
             nosotros
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="an">
            <i>
             nusatros
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="ca">
            <i>
             nosaltres
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <br/>
          (arch.
          <i>
           <span lang="ca">
            <i>
             nós
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          )
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="fr">
            <i>
             nous
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <sup>
           2
          </sup>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="it">
            <i>
             noi/noialtri
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <sup>
           3
          </sup>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="ro">
            <i>
             noi
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          'we'
         </td>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="la">
            <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
             frater germanum
            </span>
           </span>
          </i>
          <br/>
          (lit. "true brother")
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="es">
            <i>
             hermano
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="gl">
            <i>
             irmán
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="pt">
            <i>
             irmão
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="ast">
            <i>
             hermanu
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="an">
            <i>
             chirmán
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>
           <span lang="ca">
            <i>
             germà
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          <br/>
          (arch.
          <i>
           <span lang="ca">
            <i>
             frare
            </i>
           </span>
          </i>
          )
          <sup>
           4
          </sup>
         </td>
         <td>
          <i>

          </sup>

      </div>
      <p>
       <small>
        1. Also
        <i>
         <span lang="pt">
          <i>
           nós outros
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        in early modern Portuguese (e.g.
        <i>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Lusiads" title="The Lusiads">
          The Lusiads
         </a>
        </i>
        ), and
        <i>
         <span lang="gl">
          <i>
           nosoutros
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        in Galician.
        <br/>
        2. Alternatively
        <i>
         <span lang="fr">
          <i>
           nous autres
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/French_language" title="French language">
         French
        </a>
        .
        <br/>
        3. Also
        <i>
         <span lang="it">
          <i>
           noialtri
          </i>
         </span>
        </i>
        in Southern
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_languages_of_Italy" title="List of languages of Italy">
         Italian dialects and languages
        </a>
        .
        <br/>
        4. Medieval Catalan (e.g.
        <i>
         <a href="/wiki/Llibre_dels_fets" title="Llibre dels fets">
          Llibre dels fets
         </a>
        </i>
        ).
        <br/>
        5. Depending on the written norm used (see
        <a href="/wiki/Reintegrationism" title="Reintegrationism">
         Reintegrationism
        </a>
        ).
        <br/>
        6. From
        <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">
         Basque
        </a>
        <i>
         esku
        </i>
        , "hand" +
        <i>
         erdi
        </i>
        , "half, incomplete". Notice that this negative meaning also applies for Latin
        <i>
         sinistra(m)
        </i>
        ("dark, unfortunate").
        <br/>
        7. Romanian
        <i>
         caș
        </i>
        (from Latin
        <span class="smallcaps" style="font-variant:small-caps;">
         cāsevs
        </span>
        ) means a type of cheese. The universal term for cheese in Romanian is
        <i>
         brânză
        </i>
        (from unknown etymology).
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245">
         <a href="#cite_note-245">
          [245]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </small>
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Judaeo-Spanish">
        Judaeo-Spanish
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Judaeo-Spanish">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Further information:
       <a href="/wiki/Judaeo-Spanish" title="Judaeo-Spanish">
        Judaeo-Spanish
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rashiscript.PNG">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="87" data-file-width="341" height="56" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Rashiscript.PNG/220px-Rashiscript.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Rashiscript.PNG/330px-Rashiscript.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/04/Rashiscript.PNG 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rashiscript.PNG" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Rashi_script" title="Rashi script">
          Rashi script
         </a>
         , originally used to print Judaeo-Spanish.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:187px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Delacroix_letter.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="618" data-file-width="712" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Delacroix_letter.png/185px-Delacroix_letter.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Delacroix_letter.png/278px-Delacroix_letter.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Delacroix_letter.png/370px-Delacroix_letter.png 2x" width="185"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Delacroix_letter.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         An original letter in Haketia, written in 1832.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       Judaeo-Spanish, also known as Ladino,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ladino_246-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ladino-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       is a variety of Spanish which preserves many features of medieval Spanish and Portuguese and is spoken by descendants of the
       <a href="/wiki/Sephardi_Jews" title="Sephardi Jews">
        Sephardi Jews
       </a>
       who were
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alhambra_decree" title="Alhambra decree">
        expelled from Spain in the fifteenth century
       </a>
       .
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ladino_246-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ladino-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Conversely, in Portugal the vast majority of the Portuguese Jews converted and became 'New Christians'. Therefore, its relationship to Spanish is comparable with that of the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yiddish_language" title="Yiddish language">
        Yiddish language
       </a>
       to
       <a href="/wiki/German_language" title="German language">
        German
       </a>
       . Ladino speakers today are almost exclusively
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sephardim" title="Sephardim">
        Sephardi
       </a>
       Jews, with family roots in Turkey, Greece, or the Balkans, and living mostly in Israel, Turkey, and the United States, with a few communities in Hispanic America.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ladino_246-2">
        <a href="#cite_note-Ladino-246">
         [246]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Judaeo-Spanish lacks the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amerindian_languages" title="Amerindian languages">
        Native American vocabulary
       </a>
       which was acquired by standard Spanish during the
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">
        Spanish colonial period
       </a>
       , and it retains many archaic features which have since been lost in standard Spanish. It contains, however, other vocabulary which is not found in standard Spanish, including vocabulary from
       <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">
        Hebrew
       </a>
       , French, Greek and
       <a href="/wiki/Turkish_language" title="Turkish language">
        Turkish
       </a>
       , and other languages spoken where the Sephardim settled.
      </p>
      <p>
       Judaeo-Spanish is in serious danger of extinction because many native speakers today are elderly as well as elderly
       <i>
        olim
       </i>
       (immigrants to
       <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">
        Israel
       </a>
       ) who have not transmitted the language to their children or grandchildren. However, it is experiencing a minor revival among Sephardi communities, especially in music. In the case of the Latin American communities, the danger of extinction is also due to the risk of assimilation by modern Castilian.
      </p>
      <p>
       A related dialect is
       <a href="/wiki/Haketia" title="Haketia">
        Haketia
       </a>
       , the Judaeo-Spanish of northern Morocco. This too tended to assimilate with modern Spanish, during the Spanish occupation of the region.
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Writing_system">
        Writing system
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Writing system">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Spanish_orthography" title="Spanish orthography">
        Spanish orthography
       </a>
      </div>
      <table class="vertical-navbox nowraplinks hlist" style="float:right;clear:right;width:22.0em;margin:0 0 1.0em 1.0em;background:#f9f9f9;border:1px solid #aaa;padding:0.2em;border-spacing:0.4em 0;text-align:center;line-height:1.4em;font-size:88%">

       </tr>

          <img alt="Eñe on keyboard - blue.jpg" data-file-height="446" data-file-width="595" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/E%C3%B1e_on_keyboard_-_blue.jpg/175px-E%C3%B1e_on_keyboard_-_blue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/E%C3%B1e_on_keyboard_-_blue.jpg/263px-E%C3%B1e_on_keyboard_-_blue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/E%C3%B1e_on_keyboard_-_blue.jpg/350px-E%C3%B1e_on_keyboard_-_blue.jpg 2x" width="175"/>

       <tr>
        <td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;border-top:1px solid #aaa; padding-bottom:0.4em;">
         <div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
          <ul>
           <li class="nv-view">
            <a href="/wiki/Template:Spanish_language" title="Template:Spanish language">
             <abbr title="View this template">
              v
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-talk">
            <a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Spanish_language" title="Template talk:Spanish language">
             <abbr title="Discuss this template">
              t
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
           <li class="nv-edit">
            <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Spanish_language&amp;action=edit">
             <abbr title="Edit this template">
              e
             </abbr>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
        </td>
       </tr>
      </table>
      <p>
       Spanish is written in the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_script" title="Latin script">
        Latin script
       </a>
       , with the addition of the character ⟨
       <a href="/wiki/%C3%91" title="Ñ">
        ñ
       </a>
       ⟩ (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          eñe
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , representing the phoneme
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /
        <a href="/wiki/Palatal_nasal" title="Palatal nasal">
         ɲ
        </a>
        /
       </span>
       , a letter distinct from ⟨n⟩, although typographically composed of an ⟨n⟩ with a
       <a href="/wiki/Tilde" title="Tilde">
        tilde
       </a>
       ) and the
       <a href="/wiki/Digraph_(orthography)" title="Digraph (orthography)">
        digraphs
       </a>
       ⟨ch⟩ (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          che
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , representing the phoneme
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /t͡ʃ/
       </span>
       ) and ⟨ll⟩ (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          elle
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , representing the phoneme
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /
        <a href="/wiki/Palatal_lateral_approximant" title="Palatal lateral approximant">
         ʎ
        </a>
        /
       </span>
       ). However, the digraph ⟨rr⟩ (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          erre fuerte
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , 'strong r',
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          erre doble
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , 'double r', or simply
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          erre
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ), which also represents a distinct phoneme
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        /r/
       </span>
       , is not similarly regarded as a single letter. Since 1994 ⟨ch⟩ and ⟨ll⟩ have been treated as letter pairs for
       <a href="/wiki/Collation" title="Collation">
        collation
       </a>
       purposes, though they remain a part of the alphabet. Words with ⟨ch⟩ are now alphabetically sorted between those with ⟨cg⟩ and ⟨ci⟩, instead of following ⟨cz⟩ as they used to. The situation is similar for ⟨ll⟩.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247">
        <a href="#cite_note-247">
         [247]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248">
        <a href="#cite_note-248">
         [248]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <p>
       Thus, the Spanish alphabet has the following 27 letters and 2 digraphs:
      </p>
      <dl>
       <dd>
        <i>
         A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, Ñ, O, P, Q, R, S, T, U, V, W, X, Y, Z.
        </i>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249">
         <a href="#cite_note-249">
          [249]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </dd>
       <dd>
        <i>
         Ch,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250">
          <a href="#cite_note-250">
           [250]
          </a>
         </sup>
         Ll
        </i>
        .
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
         <a href="#cite_note-251">
          [251]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </dd>
      </dl>
      <p>
       The letters
       <i>
        k
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        w
       </i>
       are used only in words and names coming from foreign languages (
       <i>
        kilo, folklore, whisky, kiwi
       </i>
       , etc.).
      </p>
      <p>
       With the exclusion of a very small number of regional terms such as
       <i>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/M%C3%A9xico" title="México">
         México
        </a>
       </i>
       (see
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toponymy_of_Mexico#Phonetic_evolution" title="Toponymy of Mexico">
        Toponymy of Mexico
       </a>
       ), pronunciation can be entirely determined from spelling. Under the orthographic conventions, a typical Spanish word is stressed on the
       <a href="/wiki/Syllable" title="Syllable">
        syllable
       </a>
       before the last if it ends with a vowel (not including ⟨y⟩) or with a vowel followed by ⟨n⟩ or an ⟨s⟩; it is stressed on the last syllable otherwise. Exceptions to this rule are indicated by placing an
       <a href="/wiki/Acute_accent" title="Acute accent">
        acute accent
       </a>
       on the
       <a href="/wiki/Stress_(linguistics)" title="Stress (linguistics)">
        stressed vowel
       </a>
       .
      </p>
      <p>
       The acute accent is used, in addition, to distinguish between certain
       <a href="/wiki/Homophone" title="Homophone">
        homophones
       </a>
       , especially when one of them is a stressed word and the other one is a
       <a href="/wiki/Clitic" title="Clitic">
        clitic
       </a>
       : compare
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          el
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ('the', masculine singular definite article) with
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          él
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ('he' or 'it'), or
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          te
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ('you', object pronoun) with
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          té
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ('tea'),
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          de
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       (preposition 'of') versus
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          dé
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ('give' [formal imperative/third-person present subjunctive]), and
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          se
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       (reflexive pronoun) versus
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          sé
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ('I know' or imperative 'be').
      </p>
      <p>
       The interrogative pronouns (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          qué
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          cuál
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          dónde
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          quién
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , etc.) also receive accents in direct or indirect questions, and some demonstratives (
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          ése
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          éste
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       ,
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          aquél
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       , etc.) can be accented when used as pronouns. Accent marks used to be omitted on capital letters (a widespread practice in the days of
       <a href="/wiki/Typewriter" title="Typewriter">
        typewriters
       </a>
       and the early days of computers when only lowercase vowels were available with accents), although the
       <i>
        Real Academia Española
       </i>
       advises against this and the orthographic conventions taught at schools enforce the use of the accent.
      </p>
      <p>
       When
       <i>
        u
       </i>
       is written between
       <i>
        g
       </i>
       and a front vowel
       <i>
        e
       </i>
       or
       <i>
        i
       </i>
       , it indicates a "
       <a href="/wiki/Hard_and_soft_G" title="Hard and soft G">
        hard g
       </a>
       " pronunciation. A
       <a href="/wiki/Diaeresis_(diacritic)" title="Diaeresis (diacritic)">
        diaeresis
       </a>
       <i>
        ü
       </i>
       indicates that it is not silent as it normally would be (e.g.,
       <i>
        cigüeña
       </i>
       , 'stork', is pronounced
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [θiˈɣweɲa]
       </span>
       ; if it were written *
       <i>
        cigueña
       </i>
       , it would be pronounced *
       <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">
        [θiˈɣeɲa]
       </span>
       ).
      </p>
      <p>
       Interrogative and exclamatory clauses are introduced with
       <a href="/wiki/Inverted_question_and_exclamation_marks" title="Inverted question and exclamation marks">
        inverted question and exclamation marks
       </a>
       (
       <i>
        ¿
       </i>
       and
       <i>
        ¡
       </i>
       , respectively).
      </p>
      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Organizations">
        Organizations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Organizations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h2>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="422" data-file-width="640" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg/220px-Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg/330px-Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg/440px-Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Academia_de_la_Lengua.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Real Academia Española">
          Royal Spanish Academy
         </a>
         Headquarters in
         <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">
          Madrid
         </a>
         ,
         <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">
          Spain
         </a>
         .
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Royal_Spanish_Academy">
        Royal Spanish Academy
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Royal Spanish Academy">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Real Academia Española">
        Real Academia Española
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:62px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1036" data-file-width="746" height="83" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg/60px-Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg/90px-Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg/120px-Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg.png 2x" width="60"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Royal_Spanish_Academy.svg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Arms of the Royal Spanish Academy
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        <span lang="es">
         <i>
          Real Academia Española
         </i>
        </span>
       </i>
       (Royal Spanish Academy), founded in 1713,
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252">
        <a href="#cite_note-252">
         [252]
        </a>
       </sup>
       together with the 21 other national ones (see
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_of_Spanish_Language_Academies" title="Association of Spanish Language Academies">
        Association of Spanish Language Academies
       </a>
       ), exercises a standardizing influence through its publication of dictionaries and widely respected grammar and style guides.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253">
        <a href="#cite_note-253">
         [253]
        </a>
       </sup>
       Because of influence and for other sociohistorical reasons, a standardized form of the language (
       <a href="/wiki/Standard_Spanish" title="Standard Spanish">
        Standard Spanish
       </a>
       ) is widely acknowledged for use in literature, academic contexts and the media.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Association_of_Spanish_Language_Academies">
        Association of Spanish Language Academies
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Association of Spanish Language Academies">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Association_of_Spanish_Language_Academies" title="Association of Spanish Language Academies">
        Association of Spanish Language Academies
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1196" data-file-width="2644" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png/220px-Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png/330px-Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png/440px-Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png 2x" width="220"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Pa%C3%ADses_con_academia_de_la_lengua_espa%C3%B1ola.png" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         Countries members of the ASALE.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
          <a href="#cite_note-254">
           [254]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The Association of Spanish Language Academies (
       <i>
        Asociación de Academias de la Lengua Española
       </i>
       , or
       <i>
        ASALE
       </i>
       ) is the entity which regulates the Spanish language. It was created in Mexico in 1951 and represents the union of all the separate academies in the Spanish-speaking world. It comprises the academies of 23 countries, ordered by date of Academy foundation:
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Real_Academia_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Real Academia Española">
        Spain
       </a>
       (1713),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
        <a href="#cite_note-255">
         [255]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Colombiana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Colombiana de la Lengua">
        Colombia
       </a>
       (1871),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
        <a href="#cite_note-256">
         [256]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Ecuatoriana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Ecuatoriana de la Lengua">
        Ecuador
       </a>
       (1874),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
        <a href="#cite_note-257">
         [257]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Mexicana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Mexicana de la Lengua">
        Mexico
       </a>
       (1875),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258">
        <a href="#cite_note-258">
         [258]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Salvadore%C3%B1a_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Salvadoreña de la Lengua">
        El Salvador
       </a>
       (1876),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259">
        <a href="#cite_note-259">
         [259]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Venezolana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Venezolana de la Lengua">
        Venezuela
       </a>
       (1883),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
        <a href="#cite_note-260">
         [260]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Chilena_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Chilena de la Lengua">
        Chile
       </a>
       (1885),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
        <a href="#cite_note-261">
         [261]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academia_Peruana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Peruana de la Lengua">
        Peru
       </a>
       (1887),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262">
        <a href="#cite_note-262">
         [262]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Guatemalteca_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Guatemalteca de la Lengua">
        Guatemala
       </a>
       (1887),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263">
        <a href="#cite_note-263">
         [263]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Costarricense_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Costarricense de la Lengua">
        Costa Rica
       </a>
       (1923),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
        <a href="#cite_note-264">
         [264]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academia_Filipina_de_la_Lengua_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Academia Filipina de la Lengua Española">
        Philippines
       </a>
       (1924),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
        <a href="#cite_note-265">
         [265]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Paname%C3%B1a_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Panameña de la Lengua">
        Panama
       </a>
       (1926),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
        <a href="#cite_note-266">
         [266]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Cubana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Cubana de la Lengua">
        Cuba
       </a>
       (1926),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
        <a href="#cite_note-267">
         [267]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Paraguaya_de_la_Lengua_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Academia Paraguaya de la Lengua Española">
        Paraguay
       </a>
       (1927),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
        <a href="#cite_note-268">
         [268]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Dominicana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Dominicana de la Lengua">
        Dominican Republic
       </a>
       (1927),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
        <a href="#cite_note-269">
         [269]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Boliviana_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Boliviana de la Lengua">
        Bolivia
       </a>
       (1927),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
        <a href="#cite_note-270">
         [270]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Nicarag%C3%BCense_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Nicaragüense de la Lengua">
        Nicaragua
       </a>
       (1928),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
        <a href="#cite_note-271">
         [271]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Argentina_de_Letras" title="Academia Argentina de Letras">
        Argentina
       </a>
       (1931),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
        <a href="#cite_note-272">
         [272]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Academia_Nacional_de_Letras,_del_Uruguay" title="Academia Nacional de Letras, del Uruguay">
        Uruguay
       </a>
       (1943),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
        <a href="#cite_note-273">
         [273]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Hondure%C3%B1a_de_la_Lengua" title="Academia Hondureña de la Lengua">
        Honduras
       </a>
       (1949),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
        <a href="#cite_note-274">
         [274]
        </a>
       </sup>
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Puertorrique%C3%B1a_de_la_Lengua_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Academia Puertorriqueña de la Lengua Española">
        Puerto Rico
       </a>
       (1955),
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275">
        <a href="#cite_note-275">
         [275]
        </a>
       </sup>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/North_American_Academy_of_the_Spanish_Language" title="North American Academy of the Spanish Language">
        United States
       </a>
       (1973)
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276">
        <a href="#cite_note-276">
         [276]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Academia_Ecuatoguineana_de_la_Lengua_Espa%C3%B1ola" title="Academia Ecuatoguineana de la Lengua Española">
        Equatorial Guinea
       </a>
       (2016).
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277">
        <a href="#cite_note-277">
         [277]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </p>
      <div style="clear:left;">
      </div>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Cervantes_Institute">
        Cervantes Institute
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Cervantes Institute">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/Instituto_Cervantes" title="Instituto Cervantes">
        Instituto Cervantes
       </a>
      </div>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_(Madrid)_05.jpg">
         <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2515" data-file-width="2078" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_%28Madrid%29_05.jpg/170px-Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_%28Madrid%29_05.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_%28Madrid%29_05.jpg/255px-Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_%28Madrid%29_05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_%28Madrid%29_05.jpg/340px-Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_%28Madrid%29_05.jpg 2x" width="170"/>
        </a>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Banco_Espa%C3%B1ol_del_R%C3%ADo_de_la_Plata_(Madrid)_05.jpg" title="Enlarge">
          </a>
         </div>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cervantes_Institute" title="Cervantes Institute">
          Cervantes Institute
         </a>
         headquarters,
         <a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">
          Madrid
         </a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p>
       The
       <i>
        Instituto Cervantes
       </i>
       (Cervantes Institute) is a worldwide non-profit organization created by the Spanish government in 1991. This organization has branched out in over 20 different countries with 54 centers devoted to the Spanish and Hispanic American culture and Spanish Language. The ultimate goals of the Institute are to promote the education, the study and the use of Spanish universally as a second language, to support the methods and activities that would help the process of Spanish language education, and to contribute to the advancement of the Spanish and Hispanic American cultures throughout non-Spanish-speaking countries.
      </p>
      <h3>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Official_use_by_international_organizations">
        Official use by international organizations
       </span>
       <span class="mw-editsection">
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         [
        </span>
        <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_language&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Official use by international organizations">
         edit
        </a>
        <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
         ]
        </span>
       </span>
      </h3>
      <div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">
       Main article:
       <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_where_Spanish_is_an_official_language#International_organizations_where_Spanish_is_official" title="List of countries where Spanish is an official language">
        List of countries where Spanish is an official language § International organizations where Spanish is official
       </a>
      </div>
      <p>
       Spanish is one of the official languages of the
       <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">
        United Nations
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">
        European Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">
        World Trade Organization
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">
        Organization of American States
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">
        Organization of Ibero-American States
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">
        African Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Union_of_South_American_Nations" title="Union of South American Nations">
        Union of South American Nations
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Antarctic_Treaty_Secretariat" title="Antarctic Treaty Secretariat">
        Antarctic Treaty Secretariat
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/Latin_Union" title="Latin Union">
        Latin Union
       </a>
       , the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caricom" title="Caricom">
        Caricom
       </a>
       , the
       <a href="/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="North American Free Trade Agreement">
        North American Free Trade Agreement
       </a>
       , and numerous other international organizations.
      </p>
      <div style="clear:right;">
      </div>

              Insular Spanish
              <ul>
               <li>
                <a href="/wiki/Canarian_Spanish" title="Canarian Spanish">
                 Canarian Spanish
                </a>
               </li>
              </ul>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Americas" title="Spanish language in the Americas">
              Spanish in the Americas
             </a>
            </b>
            <ul>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/North_American_Spanish" title="North American Spanish">
               North American Spanish
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Central_American_Spanish" title="Central American Spanish">
               Central American Spanish
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Spanish" title="Caribbean Spanish">
               Caribbean Spanish
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_South_America" title="Spanish language in South America">
               South American Spanish
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_United_States" title="Spanish language in the United States">
               Spanish in the United States
              </a>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Spanish in Africa
            </b>
            <ul>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Equatoguinean_Spanish" title="Equatoguinean Spanish">
               Equatoguinean Spanish
              </a>
             </li>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Sahrawi_Arab_Democratic_Republic" title="Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic">
               Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic
              </a>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </li>
           <li>
            <b>
             Spanish in Asia
            </b>
            <ul>
             <li>
              <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language_in_the_Philippines" title="Spanish language in the Philippines">
               Spanish in the Philippines
              </a>
              <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278">
               <a href="#cite_note-278">
                [278]
               </a>
              </sup>
             </li>
            </ul>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </td>
         <td style="width: 33.33%;text-align:left;vertical-align:top;">
         </td>
        </tr>
       </table>
      </div>

        <li id="cite_note-4">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-4">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Note that in English, "Castilian" or "Castilian Spanish" may be understood as referring to
          <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_Spanish" title="Peninsular Spanish">
           European Spanish
          </a>
          ("Spanish Spanish") to the exclusion of dialects in the New World or to
          <a href="/wiki/Castilian_Spanish" title="Castilian Spanish">
           Castilian Spanish
          </a>
          to the exclusion of
          <i>
           any
          </i>
          other dialect, rather than as a synonym for the entire language.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Nationalencyklopedin-5">

           . Madrid. p. 97.

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Historia+de+la+lengua+espa%C3%B1ola&amp;rft.place=Madrid&amp;rft.pages=97&amp;rft.date=1960&amp;rft.aulast=Lapesa&amp;rft.aufirst=Raphael&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DuJdbJK_sl2oC%26pg%3DPA255&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-17">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-17">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation journal">
           Quintana, Lucía; Mora, Juan Pablo (2002).
           <a class="external text" href="http://cvc.cervantes.es/ensenanza/biblioteca_ele/asele/pdf/13/13_0697.pdf" rel="nofollow">
            "Enseñanza del acervo léxico árabe de la lengua española"
           </a>
           <span style="font-size:85%;">
            (PDF)
           </span>
           .
           <i>
            ASELE. Actas XIII
           </i>
           : 705.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=ASELE.+Actas+XIII&amp;rft.atitle=Ense%C3%B1anza+del+acervo+l%C3%A9xico+%C3%A1rabe+de+la+lengua+espa%C3%B1ola&amp;rft.pages=705&amp;rft.date=2002&amp;rft.aulast=Quintana&amp;rft.aufirst=Luc%C3%ADa&amp;rft.au=Mora%2C+Juan+Pablo&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fcvc.cervantes.es%2Fensenanza%2Fbiblioteca_ele%2Fasele%2Fpdf%2F13%2F13_0697.pdf&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          : "El léxico español de procedencia árabe es muy abundante: se ha señalado que constituye, aproximadamente, un 8% del vocabulario total"
         </span>

         <span class="reference-text">

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Presidential+Decree+No.+155+%3A+PHILIPPINE+LAWS%2C+STATUTES+and+CODES+%3A+CHAN+ROBLES+VIRTUAL+LAW+LIBRARY&amp;rft.pub=Chanrobles.com&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.chanrobles.com%2Fpresidentialdecrees%2Fpresidentialdecreeno155.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">

        <li id="cite_note-77">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-77">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Article XIV, Sec 7: "For purposes of communication and instruction, the official languages of the Philippines are Filipino and, until otherwise provided by law, English. The regional languages are the auxiliary official languages in the regions and shall serve as auxiliary media of instruction therein.
          <u>
           Spanish
          </u>
          and Arabic shall be promoted on a voluntary and optional basis."
         </span>
        </li>

          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-proyecciones_112-0">
           <a href="#cite_note-proyecciones-112">
            [112]
           </a>

        <li id="cite_note-114">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-114">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          According to Ethnologue (see
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.ethnologue.com/country/AR/languages" rel="nofollow">
            "Argentina"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            Ethnologue
           </i>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Ethnologue&amp;rft.atitle=Argentina&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ethnologue.com%2Fcountry%2FAR%2Flanguages&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
          ), there were 40,3 million speakers Spanish as mother tongue in 2013. The Argentinian population in 2013 was projected to be 42,2 million.
          <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-proyecciones_112-1">
           <a href="#cite_note-proyecciones-112">
            [112]
           </a>
          </sup>

          <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130907120032/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3876/is_199806/ai_n8805121/" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          . About 75 percent can speak Spanish.
