        <li id="cite_note-150">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-150">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          There are 150,200 people who speak another language as mother tongue,
          <cite class="citation">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.ethnologue.com/show_country.asp?name=UY" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             UY
            </i>
           </a>
           , Ethnologue
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=UY&amp;rft.pub=Ethnologue&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ethnologue.com%2Fshow_country.asp%3Fname%3DUY&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-164">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-164">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <a class="external text" href="http://eldiae.es/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/2012_el_espanol_en_el_mundo.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           Spanish in the world 2012 (Instituto Cervantes)
          </a>
          : 3,017,265 Spanish speakers. 439,000 with native knowledge, 2,557,773 with limited knowledge (page 6), and 20,492 Spanish students (page 10).
         </span>

        <li id="cite_note-165">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">

            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           Nestor Diaz: More than 2 million Spanish speakers and around 3 million with Chavacano speakers (24 April 2010).
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.aresprensa.com/cms/cms/front_content.php?idart=208" rel="nofollow">
            "FILIPINAS / Vigoroso regreso del español"
           </a>
           . Aresprensa.com
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">

           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=FILIPINAS+%2F+Vigoroso+regreso+del+espa%C3%B1ol&amp;rft.pub=Aresprensa.com&amp;rft.date=2010-04-24&amp;rft.au=Nestor+Diaz%3A++More+than+2+million+Spanish+speakers+and+around+3+million+with+Chavacano+speakers&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.aresprensa.com%2Fcms%2Fcms%2Ffront_content.php%3Fidart%3D208&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-166">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-166">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The figure of 2 900 000 Spanish speakers is in
          <cite class="citation" id="CITEREFThompson">
           Thompson, RW,
           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?ei=vCXASpS0LqXkmwO0lZnlBg&amp;ct=result&amp;q=Pluricentric+languages%3A+differing+norms+in+different+nations+spanish+philippines+speakers&amp;btnG=Buscar+libros" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Pluricentric languages: differing norms in different nations
            </i>
           </a>
           , p. 45
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Pluricentric+languages%3A+differing+norms+in+different+nations&amp;rft.pages=45&amp;rft.aulast=Thompson&amp;rft.aufirst=RW&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fei%3DvCXASpS0LqXkmwO0lZnlBg%26ct%3Dresult%26q%3DPluricentric%2Blanguages%253A%2Bdiffering%2Bnorms%2Bin%2Bdifferent%2Bnations%2Bspanish%2Bphilippines%2Bspeakers%26btnG%3DBuscar%2Blibros&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">

        <li id="cite_note-Demografía_de_la_lengua_española-187">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-Demografía_de_la_lengua_española_187-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Page 32 of
          <a class="external text" href="http://eprints.ucm.es/8936/1/DT03-06.pdf" rel="nofollow">
           Demografía de la lengua española
          </a>
          (52,1% native speakers + 11,7% with some Spanish knowledge))
         </span>
        </li>

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%D0%94%D0%B5%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%84%D0%B8%D1%8F&amp;rft.pub=Gks.ru&amp;rft.date=2011-12-27&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.gks.ru%2Fbgd%2Ffree%2FB13_00%2FIssWWW.exe%2FStg%2Fdk04%2F8-0.htm&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-UN_2009_estimate-209">

          <a class="external autonumber" href="http://cvc.cervantes.es/lengua/anuario/anuario_99/otero/p03.htm#7" rel="nofollow">

          </a>

          (2,397,000 people speak Spanish as a native language in the E.U. excluded Spain, but It is already counted population who speak Spanish as a native language in France (477,564), Italy (255,459), U.K. (120,000) Sweden (77,912) and Luxemburg (4,049)).

           (4th ed.). Houghton Mifflin Company. 2006.

          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+American+Heritage+Dictionary+of+the+English+Language&amp;rft.edition=4th&amp;rft.pub=Houghton+Mifflin+Company&amp;rft.date=2006&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-232">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-232">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           <i>
            Webster's Revised Unabridged Dictionary
           </i>
           . MICRA, Inc. 1998.
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Webster%27s+Revised+Unabridged+Dictionary&amp;rft.pub=MICRA%2C+Inc.&amp;rft.date=1998&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">

         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-233">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-233">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation encyclopaedia">
           <a class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/5kwQf5Tmd?url=http://encarta.msn.com/dictionary_1861595345/Castilian.html" rel="nofollow">
            <i>
             Encarta World English Dictionary
            </i>
           </a>
           . Bloomsbury Publishing Plc. 2007. Archived from
           <a class="external text" href="http://encarta.msn.com/dictionary_1861595345/Castilian.html" rel="nofollow">
            the original
           </a>
           on 31 October 2009
           <span class="reference-accessdate">
            . Retrieved
            <span class="nowrap">
             5 August
            </span>
            2008
           </span>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Encarta+World+English+Dictionary&amp;rft.pub=Bloomsbury+Publishing+Plc.&amp;rft.date=2007&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fencarta.msn.com%2Fdictionary_1861595345%2FCastilian.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-234">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-234">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation book">
           Penny, Ralph (2000).
           <i>
            Variation and Change in Spanish
           </i>
           . Cambridge University Press. p. 199.
           <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">
            ISBN
           </a>
           <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/0-521-78045-4" title="Special:BookSources/0-521-78045-4">
            0-521-78045-4
           </a>
           .
           <q>
            <i>
             whatever might be claimed by other centres, such as Valladolid, it was educated varieties of Madrid Spanish that were mostly regularly reflected in the written standard.
            </i>
           </q>
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Variation+and+Change+in+Spanish&amp;rft.pages=199&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=0-521-78045-4&amp;rft.aulast=Penny&amp;rft.aufirst=Ralph&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-235">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-235">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          The
          <a href="/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet" title="International Phonetic Alphabet">
           IPA
          </a>
          symbol "turned
          <i>
           y
          </i>
          " (ʎ), with its "tail" leaning to the right, resembles, but is technically different from, the Greek letter lambda (λ), whose tail leans to the left.
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-236">

          <a class="external text" href="http://www.lingref.com/cpp/wss/4/paper1755.pdf" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          . Selected Proceedings of the 4th Workshop on Spanish Sociolinguistics, ed. Maurice Westmoreland and Juan Antonio Thomas, 54–63. Somerville, MA: Cascadilla Proceedings Project, 2008.
         </span>
        </li>

        <li id="cite_note-ezglot-244">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-ezglot_244-0">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          <cite class="citation web">
           <a class="external text" href="http://www.ezglot.com/most-similar-languages.php?l=spa" rel="nofollow">
            "Similar languages to Spanish"
           </a>
           .
           <i>
            EZGlot
           </i>
           .
          </cite>
          <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=EZGlot&amp;rft.atitle=Similar+languages+to+Spanish&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ezglot.com%2Fmost-similar-languages.php%3Fl%3Dspa&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">
           <span style="display:none;">
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-245">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          <b>
           <a href="#cite_ref-245">
            ^
           </a>
          </b>
         </span>
         <span class="reference-text">
          Often considered to be a substratum word. Other theories suggest, on the basis of what is used to make cheese, a derivation from Latin
          <i>
           brandeum
          </i>
          (originally meaning a linen covering, later a thin cloth for relic storage) through an intermediate root *
          <i>
           brandea
          </i>
          . For the development of the meaning, cf. Spanish
          <i>
           manteca
          </i>
          , Portuguese
          <i>
           manteiga
          </i>
          , probably from Latin
          <i>
           mantica
          </i>
          ('sack'), Italian
          <i>
           formaggio
          </i>
          and French
          <i>
           fromage
          </i>
          from
          <i>
           formaticus
          </i>
          .
          <a class="external text" href="http://dexonline.ro./definitie/brânză" rel="nofollow">
           Romanian Explanatory Dictionary
          </a>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li id="cite_note-Ladino-246">
         <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
          ^
          <a href="#cite_ref-Ladino_246-0">

             </b>

           </sup>

            <i>
             <b>
              c
             </b>
            </i>

          </a>
         </span>

           <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/?id=eEWZL1j9ig8C&amp;pg=PA4&amp;dq=real+academia+espa%C3%B1ola+recognized#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false" rel="nofollow">

          <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-521-16823-6" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-521-16823-6">
           978-0-521-16823-6
          </a>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Los+sonidos+del+espa%C3%B1ol&amp;rft.pub=Cambridge+University+Press&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-521-16823-6&amp;rft.aulast=Hualde&amp;rft.aufirst=Jos%C3%A9+Ignacio&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1a3CAQAAQBAJ%26pg%3DPR14%26dq%3D%2522fonemas%2Bconson%25C3%25A1nticos%2522%26hl%3Den%26sa%3DX%26ved%3D0ahUKEwjzrYWB-7rJAhUL3mMKHVmZAVIQ6AEIWDAH%23v%3Donepage%26q%3D%2522fonemas%2520conson%25C3%25A1nticos%2522%26f%3Dfalse&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">

      <h2>
       <span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">

       <span class="mw-editsection">

         [

       <li>

         </a>
         .
         <i>
          <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">
           The Economist
          </a>
         </i>
         . 1 June 2013.
        </cite>
        <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Economist&amp;rft.atitle=Hats+Off%3A+The+Rise+of+Spanish&amp;rft.date=2013-06-01&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.economist.com%2Fnews%2Fbooks-and-arts%2F21578631-spanish-has-more-native-speakers-any-language-other-mandarin-yet-its-success&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ASpanish+language">

                             <li>
                              <a href="/wiki/Ladin_language" title="Ladin language">
                               Ladin
                              </a>
                             </li>
                             <li>
                              <a href="/wiki/Romansh_language" title="Romansh language">
                               Romansh
                              </a>
                             </li>
                            </ul>
                           </div>
                          </td>
                         </tr>
                        </table>
                       </td>

                    </td>

              </td>

             <tr>
              <td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2">
               <div>
                <div class="hlist hlist-separated">
                 <ul>
                  <li>
                   <i>
                    Italics
                   </i>
                   indicate
                   <a href="/wiki/Language_death" title="Language death">
                    extinct languages
                   </a>
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   <b>
                    Bold
                   </b>
                   indicates
                   <a href="/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers" title="List of languages by number of native speakers">
                    languages with more than 5 million speakers
                   </a>
                  </li>
                  <li>
                   Languages between parentheses are
                   <a href="/wiki/Variety_(linguistics)" title="Variety (linguistics)">
                    varieties
                   </a>
                   of the language on their left.
                  </li>
                 </ul>
                </div>
               </div>
              </td>

                 </li>

                  <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Faroe_Islands" title="Languages of the Faroe Islands">
                   Faroe Islands
                  </a>

                   Guernsey
                  </a>

                 <li>
                  <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Isle_of_Man" title="Languages of the Isle of Man">
                   Isle of Man
                  </a>
                 </li>

                  <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Jersey" title="Languages of Jersey">
                   Jersey
                  </a>

                  </a>

                </ul>
               </div>
              </td>
             </tr>
